item.title: What is Critical Practice
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
• Critical practice affords a sense of perspective on the context into which you are designing.It develops and raises awareness which allows for this sense of perspective to be cultivated.
  • Use of research methods and processes which inform, ventilate and begin to reveal the essence of the context into which you design. This can also create new 'worlds' and 'spaces'.
  • An informed and holistic approach to design which is in awareness of the systemic impact of designing 'worlds' and 'things' and their ongoing designing in the world.

item.title: How do you know where to act?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
• Lefebvres' Projective Retrojective method - informs the real world situated context of the design through primary and secondary research which is unique to the context of each investigation.
  • Reading around the subject area. Understanding the social, political and economic contexts.
  • Using your senses to go and look where there is a need for action.
  • Being aware of subjectivity and the selective nature of perception.

item.title: How does CP manifest itself in academic vs professional practice?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: In an academic context critical practice can perhaps be more experimental and aim to address spaces where there is a observed need for action, whereas in a professional practice there will be a profit-driven end and the context is more likely to be preconfigured.

item.title: Research standpoints / positions
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
phenomenological
  • the study of conscious experience
ethnographic
  • see James Clifford
studies people, ethnic groups and other ethnic formations, theirethnogenesis, composition, resettlement, social welfare characteristics, as well as their material and spiritual culture.[2] It is often employed for gatheringempirical data on humansocieties andcultures. Data collection is often done through participant observation, interviews, questionnaires, etc. Ethnography aims to describe the nature of those who are studied (i.e. to describe a people, anethnos) through writing.[3] In the biological sciences, this type of study might be called a "field study" or a "case report," both of which are used as common synonyms for "ethnography".[4] (Wikipedia)
emancipatory
Emancipation is a broad term used to describe various efforts to obtainpolitical rights orequality, often for a specificallydisenfranchised group, or more generally in discussion of such matters. Emancipation stems from "ex manus capere": Take out the hand. Among others,Karl Marx discussed political emancipation in his 1844 essay "On the Jewish Question", although often in addition to (or in contrast with) the termhuman emancipation. Marx's views of political emancipation in this work were summarized by one writer as entailing "equal status of individual citizens in relation to the state, equality before the law, regardless of religion, property, or other private characteristics of individual people."[1]
participatory Participation is when action research feminist research deconstruction

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This resource began as a university project (MA Design Critical Practice - Goldsmiths) about Design Methods. I have expanded it beyond the original brief. There seems to be a great deal of potential in the material and the challenge is develop strategies and systems for using the methods. Although many of the methods are related to design, the scope of use goes far beyond this. It is being actively developed.

item.title: City Survival Manifesto
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
City Survival Manifesto
1. Get a bike and keep it well maintained (get a helmet and a good lock D-Locks are best. Get helmet, gloves, puncture repair kit, pump, tyre lever and allen keys keep in portable repair kit) 2. Get a good small rucksack / bag which is comfortable. Keep a waterproof coat, hat, gloves, A to Z, wallet, bike tools, bike lock in it. 3. Get a large rucksack for shopping trips 4. Shop in local grocers and butchers instead of supermarkets (cheaper & fresher) 5. Get an A to Z map & a compass for orientating the map 6. Accept invitations 7. Look up at the sky once in a while (good for remembering you are on planet earth & picking out tall landmarks) 8. Get a key chain that clips to your jeans / trouser belt loop which holds your keys (incl. bike lock keys) 9. Dont carry loads of money in your wallet (so you dont spend it) 10. Be friendly 11. Be observant 12. Dont run the red lights 13. Be on time 14. Ask for directions from people rather than using your iphone

item.title: Expedition Preparation Manifesto
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: 1. Choose your expedition partners wisely. 2. Less is more. Only take what you really need. 3. Have a clear goal and focus- dont let this be blurred by adding extra things. 4. Gear is overrated. Choose the best gear, but do your research. Choose wisely and minimal items of proven quality and standards will serve you well. Some items are tried and tested e.g. a good sleeping bag to keep you warm. 5. Dont under or over estimate your budget. 6. Set a day to leave. Leaving is often said to be the most difficult part. 7. Make a journal, camera- video and still, if possible, to record and communicate your trip. 8. Involve other people. Spread the word, start a website. Tell everyone you meet about your plans. Develop a readership for a blog and form connections and build your network. 9. Stay open minded. The aim of any expedition is to learn and be open to the experience. If opportunities arise and there is time to spend to look into them, do it, as long as its not at the expense of achieving your goals. 10. Consider the environment. If your mode of transport is heavy on the Co2 emissions, take steps to cut down.

item.title: Motivational Manifesto
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: 1. Change your scenery. Get on a train and go somewhere else for a weekend. Get on your bike and go for a spin for a couple of hours. 2. Get out of your comfort zone. Its a difficult one to do but normally feels great afterwards. You can get out of your comfort zone by doing something you fear or making things less comfortable! 3. Meet up with other people. Being with other people is energising and stimulates ideas. 4. Do some exercise. Getting the blood moving is guaranteed to awake you from stagnation. Go out for a run. 5. Get outside. There is no substitute for getting outside for some fresh air. 6. Set yourself a goal. Tell yourself that you are going to finish something you really want to finish by the end of the day. Dont stop until its done. Set the time scale realistically for any task otherwise you risk being disappointed but always aim to push yourself. You will be surprised at the results. 7. Get organised. Do everything you can to remove distractions in your life. Sell useless things on Ebay. Remove all online addictions like Facebook. If you work on a computer; take time to make sure it runs properly. Organise your files and folders and back it up so you dont lose your work. Get your tools in order, whatever they may be in your life. 8. Read about other people doing the same stuff that you are interested in. I often read the blogs of people doing adventurous things and I study design websites to get inspired in my work. 9. Focus. Trying to do to many things at once just dissipates your energy. You need to focus on one, max two tasks. 10. Finish one thing before you start another. There is nothing more demoralising than having a load of loose ends and nothing properly finished. Everything is a process but learn to know when something is finished and when it needs perseverance. 11. Get angry. Look at your life and if youre not living your wildest dreams, understand why you arent, and then start to take actions to change things. Angst is a word in Existentialism that describes the anxiety or energy that is felt through a dissatisfaction with life and the need to make the big leap and commit yourself to your goals. 12. Help others. There is nothing more rewarding than helping people in need and contributing to a worthwhile cause. If you cant get motivated by a social project then youve got problems. 13. Read philosophy. Philosophies are ideas about how to live life. In the past a lot of clever people have pondered the reasons for existence and come up with various conclusions. Many of these can provide relevant ways to live life today, and some cant, but thats up to you. 14. Watch films, go the the theatre. Acting is an important part of human culture. It allows humans to step out of the rigid structures of societal etiquette and go nuts. Acting is all about energy. Energy is what you need to get motivated. If you are energetic other people will thrive on that energy. 15. Collaborate. There is nothing better for getting motivated on a goal than sharing that goal with someone else. If you start to get demotivated, chances are someone else in the team will still be buzzing off the idea, and can lift you up, and vice verse. Human brains work through free association. One idea leads to another, and another etc etc. More brains mean exponentially more ideas. Ideas are exciting and what you need for the process to achieve your goals. 16. Learn lateral thinking. Lateral thinking is different to vertical thinking in that it is concerned with the generation of ideas. Vertical thinking is the logical linear process of one train of thought. It requires you to be right at each step. Lateral thinking doesnt require you to be right at each step and in fact its possible to jump steps. Being wrong is not bad in lateral thinking. 17. Clear your mind. Take some time out. In the western world we wind ourselves up something chronic and we cant tell why were all crazy. Take a day to do NOTHING. See how you feel the next day. NOTHING doesnt include vegging out in front of the telly, grrrrr! 18. Make the most of the situation. If it snows, take a leaf out of the book of the Swedish (book?). Run a hot bath, then run out into the snow, roll in it and then get into bath. Repeat. If that doesnt wake you up 19. Procrastinate usefully. If you cant do something you really want to do right now for circumstances out of your control or you are finding yourself unable to concentrate on something you should, do something else you can do and focus on that instead. 20. Look. Observe the greatness around you. Take up photography and spend some time looking closer at things. See the world from a different perspective.

item.title: Mini Project 1: What really matters to me?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Being very conscious and noticing people who are responding in a positive way towards me. I hope that from being like this, community and the things that I value will come to me. I have found this to be successful in the past year. Maintaining strong consciousness is powerful because it allows me to be flexible yet maintain a true direction.
Before this last year I would perhaps have mentioned a list of activities but now I realise they are footnotes to the above.
Some activities can put me into states of flow and absorption: coding, writing, windsurfing, mountain biking, cycling, love, conversation, singing, dancing, research.
Some things feedback in a more positive way. They are all exercises of the mind and body. They all require consciousness: attention, meditation.
By 'being conscious' I also have: attention to detail, awareness of my self and relation to others, my own desires and beliefs, what is generally on my mind as well as how I treat myself in terms of health and also my long term existence.
Consciousness and flow are 'key' to 'being' in a strong way and being open to what is coming and becoming. A logical approach to creating a design is as important for communicating that idea as the 'flow' aspect of it. I have been interested in Chaos and flow since I first heard about them as concepts 10 years ago.
The system or tool of society is a way that people can communicate with each other and an awareness of other conscious beings. How it frames this communication is a key question.
How to communicate a creative artefact to a community matters because it is about considering the other. Some things I have made I have invested into with the idea of presenting them to a wider audience: my book, film, projects I want to take forward from university.
A creative environment with ideas, conversations and intelligent people keeps my mind working and in this situation I am happy.
The question of the future matters to me because of its importance for future generations.
My ideas matter to me. Focussing my ideas down important.
Being open to my own 'becoming'.
'Being in the world' matters. I cannot be in front of a computer all of the time consuming digital culture. The world is a place of important learning and I don't just mean 'the world within the world'.
I have always felt connected with the world and I find it easy to adopt concepts of not privileging the anthropocentric point of view, or subject-object. I have always been in connection with non-humans, whether playing in fields when younger, being on my uncle's farm or hearing about my father's childhood as the son of a butcher. There was always a lot of 'realness'.
Cities matter. Thats where people are. People matter because of how fascinating they are; their behaviour, prejudices, psychological behaviours, group mentality, reactions to fear, desire to be safe and protected, protect their young, hypocrisies and beliefs etc.
I cannot leave my point of view as a human. The things I observe in others are my own curiosities.
Love is important to me because it takes me away from myself. At some point I hope I will be happy to devote myself to love fully with the right person or situation or however that may manifest itself.
Time and commitment are the only ways to build meaningful relationships. People (and others) need the chance to get to trusting and finding their position (or not a position).
My practice is somewhat complicating. I wish in some ways I didnt have so many interests. Music is important to me. It gets me into a flow state.
A flow state can also be a bad thing to get into when in fact you need to be still and reflect. If the flow state is to do with making or doing.
Making music is an act of craft and it getting responses from other people is central to it. It can be a personal meditation.
I create artistic images. This is a pure form of expression. Not so constrained. Doesn't have to consider the other.
I have created graphic designs which is a much more logical, rational process, with a splash of creativity. More of a balancing act between poetic and logical making. Always constrained. Has to consider the other.
I have created websites. I find coding to be an absorbing activity. I don't fully understand the process. It is both logical and poetic making, but the substance is difficult to describe.
It is a somewhat more mathematical process than graphic design which relies more on the visual consciousness. Coding is to do with abstract logical thinking, systems and utter attention to detail. It is part hacking, reliant on community and the underlying structure of a language. Mechanical and practical. It is a useful conceptual universe to have an understanding of especially when so much digital is being creating.
I generally know how it works. I have an understanding of relational database theory and programming and have built databases and applications that use databases.
I understand computers as maps of information. I have spent a great deal of time using computers. I rely on them for thinking and for making in many ways. I am very critical of them. They have augmented my life more than taken away but at what expense?
This is not a valid question because there is not no alternative. They are not something that are possible to get away from. They are everywhere and so it is better to understand how they work and fail than not.
I am interesting in film and photography because of how it relates to observation. Images are to be handled with care and even more so with the capability to collect thousands of hours of digital images and footage and being swamped in them.
Film and how it relates to consciousness is interesting. It has amazing power to feed experiences back into consciousness in how it captures consciousness and leaves an enduring imprint.
Film differs to text in how text requires the effort of reading and the effort of the imagination and comprehension. Film can quickly appeal to defined, familiar visual symbolisation and categories. E.g. Hollywood films are generally formulaic.
Writing, coding, technical abilities, images and filming, making, practical activities such as guiding, teaching and building can yield monetary gain and increasingly the ability to offer my critical knowledge and experiences and ideas in relation to a project.
De-sign is making sense of things. It sits more happily on the rational, categorising side of the creative process but encapsulates the poetic side by its reversal.
Design is extended consciousness, changing the world without hurting, communicating and being with the other and finding common ground. It is being political.
Epistemological learning has given me concepts which have filled gaps where I perhaps hadn't made up my mind, but I may never have ever been able to explore paths that would have lead me to have been able to fulfil that learning through a natural process. Epistemological learning is always a stub, a beginning, a way marker, a point of punctuation. Its what you do with it that transforms it. It is the reading of the learning that brings it alive.
The kernel of what I want to bring to the world is the importance of an adventurous approach to living but with a respect of time, tacit knowledge and commitment, how to communicate to people to bring transformative change on important issues such as the environment.
Being with people in community contexts is exciting and being in wild places. I enjoy being in highly designed situation but not to live forever.
The Exigencies of my existence are my limitations as a human being- directional, life span, the need to urinate and excrete waste, monetary means and culture that I grew up in of native context, powers of domination and control.
My weaknesses are my tendency to be exploratory in my ideas and not focus enough, so I am aware of this need to focus as well as learning about the need to commit and develop deeper bonds over time.

item.title: Film Manifesto: Theory
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Human presence
  • Having good inputs - food, sensory inputs. Concerned with core consciousness to extend consciousness and provide conditions for extended consciousness
  • Concerns everyday life habits
  • Not putting off dealing with problems. A problem is something not beneficial. Not dealing with it can be due to laziness, fear or loss of attention.
  • Being present. Direct experience / second hand experience. Not concentrating on ideas of end rather having the idea in mind whilst also being present, Not too much preparation or focus on technical equipment
  • Interacting with and modifying and changing the environment (field of view, or arrangement of objects, material conditions of consciousness)
  • Maintaining consciousness. Attention to meditation.
  • Seeing more objectively. Awareness of selective nature of perception. [affected by] Coded way of seeing-genetic and previous object of consciousness. What catches the attention.
  • Observation. Object awareness.
  • Problem of categorising- male/female. Binary opposites. Problem of systems. Coding. The tool of society.
Human Relationships
  • Possibility of community and conversation.
  • Law of communication requires that there is space between communicators. Law of proximity (Paul Virilio) and law of gaps.
  • Not putting off dealing with problems.
  • Emotions in decision making. 'Emotions and their biological underpinnings are involved in decision-making (both positively and negatively, and often non-consciously)'- Damasio. 'we may be unable to decide using only cognitive processes, which may become overloaded and unable to help us decide.''When we have to make complex and uncertain decisions, the somatic markers created by the relevant stimuli are summed to produce a net somatic state. This overall state directs (or biases) our decision of how to act.' 1 meaning that you can trust your intuition if your consciousness is clean.
Objects and object relationships
  • Objects interacting with each other, leaving traces constituting history.
  • The human is a network of objects in a symbiotic relationship.
  • Persons and their body and mental objects interacting with environmental objects.
Consiousness:
  • Consciousness is what is generally on your mind - when you wake, in your habits, what emerges in your thoughts, emotions, what catches your attention -> is generally on your mind. It is a feedback loop (with thought and environment).
  • Consciousness is as much about what is out there as in here- (Steigler insists that changes in material organisation bring about changes in the organisation of consciousness and experience. Such changes mark the development of a new stage in evolution that of epiphylogenesis in which humans overcome their genetic heritage and develop new ways of being through technological innovation. 3)
  • Clarity of sensory perception
  • Objects through time
Technics (memory tool)
  • Technics are methods of remembering and accessing the past and the future through technical systems e.g. writing allows for recording of the past and re-presentation. It affectively sets up loops of consciousness. Writing is a slow method of doing this and each reader may read the text differently. However, the film medium is more prescriptive.
  • A wider issue is whether humans can gain control over their own use of the technics or the technics themselves are too strongly creating these consciousness feedback loops.
  • What do you want to re-present in consciousness - capturing consciousness through film medium?
  • Consciousness and film feedback loop. Seeing like film. Film like seeing.
Refs: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Somatic_markers_hypothesis 1 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technics_and_Time,_1 2 http://emotionsblog.history.qmul.ac.uk/?p=934 3 Further reading: www.film-philosophy.com/2006v10n2/crogan.pdf Other theories: Actor Network Theory Ethnographic research

item.title: Chaos, Weird Rituals and Plasticity
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Recently I was watcing some of the philosopher Slavoj Zizek talking about nature (Examined Life). He was talking about the problem of ecology as a new type of idealogy and all the probably unintentional scaremongering by well-meaning environmental organisations being a secular version of the religious story of the fall.
Zizek says that the idea of 'nature' has become misconstrued and in fact he says 'there is no nature'. 'Nature is a series of gigantic catastrophes'. Taking it further in another documentary, the autobiographical 'Zizek' that there is in fact 'nothing' of any meaning and meaning is something that we give to the world. My intuitive response is that I agree with this. Certainly it gives a new and interesting perspective on the question of why I like going into untouched wilderness like Mongolia rather than it being to gawp at the pristine beauty of nature or whatever. There isn't a lot of places like this left, nowhere left for explorers to discovery etc etc.
I've always been tentatively interested in Chaos theory and dynamic systems throughout my first degree in Environmental, Economics and Ecology; population dynamics and interesting ecological systemic systems. In music, I often enjoy weird experimental music; jazz, leftfield, and have been fascinated with all the strange noises you can make with computers.
On my travels it's often the really weird rituals that is the most interesting- like watching a strange hindu ritual in Southern India; dancing and movement, colours, fire, strange costumes, face paint, drumming through the night; human behaviour that just defies 'common sense'. Energy that creates, shakes up, rearranges, displaces.
Back to Zizek. He says 'Humans have a vested interest in Catastrophe'. Having recently read Mark Buchanan his book Nexus about networks, self-organising systems, viruses, and researched entropy for an essay I wondered that not only to humans have a vested interest in chaos and catastrophe, but we invite it and indeed cultivate it. See Risk homeostatis (Wikipedia).
"The hypothesis of risk homeostasis holds that everyone has his or her own fixed level of acceptable risk. When the level of risk in one part of the individual's life changes, there will be a corresponding rise or fall in risk elsewhere to bring the overall risk back to that individual's equilibrium. Wilde argues that the same is true of larger human systems, e.g. a population of drivers."
Is it a yearning to get back to more an ecological system which makes more sense on a deeper level?
This idea of calculating and managing risk interests me because by considering that humans actually do put themselves in positions of risk seems contrary to my perception of how most people perceive risk as being something to avoid. I recently found an article by a psychologist at Goldsmiths called 'The hazards of experiential avoidance', talking about how by avoiding trying new things outright due to the perceived potential discomfort we might experience, we might be preventing the possibility of finding something better. This also applies to a perceived need to reduce distractions as being something bad as opposed to staying open to new information.
There are different types of behaviours and strategies for individuals in an ecological context of course, but often it seems that this is forgotten and rather social norms dictate the perceived proper way to act (at least in the public view- I'm not accounting for what I can't see e.g. how people actually behave in their own homes when no one is watching). Perhaps I am reflecting more my own personal subjectivity here or my cultural context being in London, but I also draw from my observations whilst travelling.
A recent reading of Malabou's "What Should we do with our brains" talks of the brain's plasticity and recent neuroscientific findings and implications for society and thinking. She talks of the dangers of business practice miscontruing the term as being concerning the ability of workers to be flexible and able to turn their hands to anything at the whim of the employer. Malabou stresses the importance of plasticity as concerning adaptability. Flexibility concerns a top-down approach, but adaptability is more about the decisions coming from the individual as to how they want to shape their own Self and identity and the importance of protecting this sense of Self. She also writes of the unfortunate consequences of depression resulting from being alienated from a network or group for not conforming to this idea of turning to any new task which one is given.
To bring this together, I would say that humans naturally need new experiences, calculated risk and chaos, and it feels good to go into beautiful untouched natural because it's a way of reconnecting with these kind of structures. Humans indeed learn from experiences, outer and inner. Indeed the outer experiences help to shape the inner and vice versa. It's essential for this dynamic and shaping occur to formulate critical self reflection and reflection on the other for the benefit of survival of the individual and the wider organism and it's different scales of community and organisation.
Next time you feel like you're being told to do something you don't agree with, yeah, perhaps give it a try to see what it's like, but don't be afraid to stand up for your reflections as they are developed, and equally don't be afraid to get stuck in whether it's for the purposes of trying something new or just for observational / meditative purposes.
With the problems of subjectivity and perceptions overcome as much as possible, (I interpret as reaching enlightment), Zizek, speaking of Brian Victoria's Zen at War, says that becoming authentic doesn't stop people from committing unethical acts. So onto ethics...

item.title: Encounters With The Real
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
--------- Edit 04/12: -------
The Real is the objective, not-fully, knowable; in other words 'god'. The Real is everything and everywhere and it cannot be known because it changes continuously and is not observable by humans in its entirity or by looking at it through the lens of any one fixed reality. The only way to get closer to The Real or to 'god' is through increasing consciousness through methods that are beyond the level reached by the western mind. The Real is not theorisable and there is more to life than theory. This path of raising consciousness is the only path that leads to higher dimensions of being. The path is a practical course and works through different levels; in India these levels are associated with chakhra points. The ultimate aim of this path is liberation and involves inner work and work to support the body and allow for resources to be devoted to this path of transformation to 'enlightenment'. The role of design and art in general is to create interventions that bring this energy of liberation and freedom to a world of conflict which is due to people living in endless subjective realities constructed by their values and belief systems.
Hiking is one exercise to meditate on open space, nature and get energy flowing round the body. Adventure is the path and energy devoted to bringing experience that progresses the path towards enlightenment.
--------- end edit ---------
Ive been at university reading Zizek and Lacan talking about social reality and The Real or Baudrillards Desert of the Real and concept of Hyperreality, or Timothy Morton talking about The Mesh and Strange Strangers. It seems clearer. I think I understand a little better why adventure is so important (to me).
Adventure is precisely the activity that humans need for progress and survival, because it allows them to learn about The Real World that exists between the cracks (mostly unseen) of everyday reality.
An example to illustrate: Reality is your daily routine, it is what you see on the news, it is your perception of the world. It is selective and directed towards the organisms needs. The Real World on the other hand is what exists completely detached from individual (and collective) human existence, from your human-being from your personal world, network, ecosystem that supports your existence in the form of a fleshy humanoid.
Reality is the human construct. It is the coordinates of what makes sense in the world, it is the enframing technology of language (it can be explained with language). However, is it not entirely possible that it at some points fails to make sense like it should? Or in a personal sense, feelings (emotions) significations of consciousness arise and signify that something should be done to enable the organism to satisfice to do what it (possibly the Selfish Gene sorry limits of my understanding here) needs to do.
Humans have learnt to protect themselves using clever skills of making- perhaps it was always going to turn out this way. Where are we now and why did I ever feel the need and still do to make the case for adventure, exploration and learning?
Humans have protected themselves, so well, in fact because of their weakness, that we now have various layers of physical and mental gateways, boundaries, borders, portals, screens, barrierers, bureaucracy (whatever forms they takes) that exist.
An example: representational media: We see something that represents The Real World reproduced through technological devices (like a video camera) that sees like humans see (but a bit differently: hint therefore useful), and then these representations through their sublime-ness become more valued than the Real itself (which we dont know and have no way of knowing or controlling fully) and also of the activity of exploration itself.
An example would be to be sitting watching an image on a movie screen in an theatre of a huge wave about to engulf a city whilst outside it is actually happening to the theatre in real time = full 3D cinema experience, scratch and sniff, immersive, sensory and ultimately fatal.
This is a problem with human ideology towards The Real World: wrong ways to think about Nature and (still) thinking (egocentric modern era- the period of the most intensive materialisation of essentially humans protecting themselves from the Real and viewing Nature purely as a resource) that humans rule the earth.
I (and I think we all) need adventure (in whatever form that takes) to keep learning about The Real World, but I also need a balance. I need to make sure that the representation doesnt supercede the will to do more learning and I dont want to get caught in that romanticised idea of wilderness = freedom from society vis a vis Into the Wild which was loss of survival instinct, essentially suicide, freedom through death.
In that film, did the characters that the protagonist met along the way represent various other paths of life: whether it was the primitivist hippies in the camper van, or the elderly man with the military ego who climbs to the top of the hill, or Supertramps mother and father who are concerned with fitting into the appearances of society? Each one offers a variant path with differing levels of learning available. I dont believe they are equivalent and can be made so by calling on relativism.
Adventure always comes with risk, but also with great benefits to individuals and wider communities of learning. That American film, that chooses to ignore that the rest of the world exists, could be construed as a kind of reproach for those who chose to do truly adventurous things?
The message there is: do be prepared but not to the point it stops seeing from happening, or worse still affects consciousness to the point that its not possible to be there in the experience, at the time, in the place. Keep learning.

item.title: Film, Nature and Objects
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I am off to a remote corner of South West Ireland next week for some walking in the rugged mountains and lakes of the area. I am looking forward to making a fire and sitting by it after a long day outside with wind burn on my face, completely exhausted.
There are numerous walks in the area, and I will be taking a camera to document the journey. I have many new ideas for filming since studying my MA course that have changed since I filmed my solo bike trips. I have explored different areas of making and I found myself still intrigued as much by film as I did when I first got my hands on a second hand video camera back in 2007.
I am going to look at the landscape and try to break down what it is about Nature or the landscape which many find awe inspiring and impressive. Last weekend I was looking out over the Chiltern Hills taking a rest on a walk there and looked out over views of the countryside and a town below.
There is something quite astonishing and cerebral about the image of a landscape, over there that doesnt apply to the same rules as looking at things in the near distance. Maybe it is something to do with being able to judge how objects are in relation to each other in the near distance e.g. that tree is 10m away and there is another behind it that breaks down looking at objects in the distance.
Instead it appears to my human eyes as a kind of more or less flat textural plain. I have to infer the positioning of things through rationally thinking about them, use my knowledge of how light affects how things look further away and any prior knowledge of the landscape I have.
Something in the distance, if you are travelling towards it, is coming up. You will arrive there if you keep going in the same speed towards it. If something is closer, this logic doesnt apply because I know I can for example, get up and walk across the room 5m to some object. However, if I moved a lot more slowly, say if I was a snail, then then logic would apply.
So there is a threshold somewhere for humans (and other organisms of similar disposition) where something becomes over there. At that point, thinking changes. In order to have the motivation to move towards the thing over there you have to convince yourself that you will eventually reach it, even though there is no direct conscious experience of it. Does this logic not just apply to moving from one place to another but to moving towards any kind of object in general mental or physical. If I am working towards something then I have to keep motivating myself to continue in order to get too it.
When I was cycling then, if I knew I had a long way to go, my mind would drift, and I would get into the zone. It seems like this into the zone state is partly a kind of coping mechanism for dealing with the directional and functional limitations of the human organism.
This state of absorption is revered by sportsmen and makers alike. It is interesting how cognitive functioning occurs during the process, particularly of movement and journeys. Does this way of seeing the world not affect how we build the world around us?
Is how we build the world around us not a somewhat unconscious way of dealing with these functional limitations and attempting to expand and overcome them through the use of technology.
Take a human and put them in a matrix style space of white nothingness. Soon we can find that there is of course something there- gravity, the floor beneath their feet, air to breathe, physics etc. If we add a chair the human can chose to sit in it which expands their ability to rest. What is going on in the mind of the human is as much about what other things are out there in the world too. This is a feedback loop. It is a good thing to know.
Hence why freedom is not a freedom of being out there somewhere in Nature, but rather away from so many objects that are thoroughly bound up with consciousness and being whether that is the chair, sofa, table, laptop, cooker, coffee table, desk etc.
If I leave an environment with all these objects in and I travel through a range of other environments, I come into contact with many different configurations of objects and their relationships.
This is incredibly interesting because we can find out a lot about the mode of existence by looking at the objects. We dont have to so much get into the mind of a subject. Hence the power of objects.
Communicating my ideas through the film media is part of the learning curve and challenge. Even though I have spent many ideas shooting footage from my bike trip from England to India, hardly any of it has had an opportunity to feed back to my learning because it was waiting in an archive for the production of the film which is now Janapar which uses mostly Toms footage.
Nevertheless, taking into account how the environment feeds back into me I should be able to film things that catch my attention baring in mind my ideas about objects, traces of journeys, histories and all of these inter object relationships, the non-human world, Nature etc and then represent edited versions of what I select to myself in order to further refine a train of investigation.

item.title: How do Objects Withdraw from Each Other
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
------ Edit 29/04 ----- This post was originally inspired by a new theory in philosophy called 'object oriented ontology' however it has recently come to me that this branch of western thinking is an observation of aspects of consciousness. Everything is consciousness. It depends on the level of consciousness. This post is an observation of the limitations of human ability to know 'The Real'. These observations are fine but observation in general is the key to enlightenment. The theories of the mind can only end up going round in circles. They are only tools for use to direct the path towards enlightenment. True learning comes from observations born from concentration and are dependent on the individual's work to enhance their awareness and consciousness. Each person has a path and therefore as much work as possible should be done on developing that path as opposed to learning some theories and descriptions that have emerged from someone else's path. It is fine to observe these things but it is good to remember that they will not lead anywhere ultimately. ------ End edit -------
1. They have homes which they go to e.g. a mouse in a hole or a human in a house 2. they have different ways of perceiving time (so appear fast or slow to others) 3. Sight is restricted to the aspect of the object 4. Senses are different - e.g. between a fly seeing and a dog seeing 5. Language / communication signs are different 6. Physical constraints e.g. only one person can stand in one area of cartesian space at one tie / therefore different observation points 7. Geographical constraints - they are somewhere else 8. You can only see the traces e.g moles and mole hills 9. Age - amount of time of consciousness amount of experience in the world 10. Or completely different period of time of existence e.g. humans and dinosaurs 11. There is no record made of its existence that is able to be seen or perceived (although it can never be destroyed to nothing) 12. Something is hidden and there is no way of investigating it. It is at the whim of movement of other objects. 13. It has fallen in a particular way. 14. There is no energy for further properties to emerge 15. Depends on the way consciousness works. They may only be unconsciously experienced until they break. 16. Have no direct access e.g. sound waves travelling through the air hitting ear drum. 17. Haven't spent long enough or didn't get long enough to spend observing the object. 18. They are busy working on each other 19. It is an evolutionary trait to be hidden 20. Hidden behind a structure / contained within a structure e.g. blood under skin, post inside parcel / envelope 21. Risk means structures of protection are put in place. 22. Natural things burst forth from a complex world into a complex world and are predisposed to make do genetic structure / support family or construct e.g. nest, burrow 23. Distracted from seeing. Effects of perception of other things. 24. Things die / decompose / fragment 25. Chemical / physical properties cause them to be unable to be perceived by the senses of the other.
* All things are interrelated * Selected out emotionally * Sensual objects vs Real Objects * Perceptual, sensorial, anatomical different, different drives * Many of the above are perceptual issues

item.title: Psychogeography
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_565" align="alignnone" width="314" caption="Psychogeography by Merlin Coverley"][/caption] Psychogeography is the process whereby an individual or a group of people go on a journey through a space or environment. It is inspired by the Situationist Internationale's theory of the 'Derive'. The participants monitor the affect of the environment on them, particularly focussing on the emotional, subconscious affects, energy and flows that usually go unnoticed in day to day routine movements. Psychogeography was defined in 1955 by Guy Debord as: the study of the precise laws and specific effects of the geographical environment, consciously organized or not, on the emotions and behavior of individuals. Another definition is: a whole toy box full of playful, inventive strategies for exploring citiesjust about anything that takes pedestrians off their predictable paths and jolts them into a new awareness of the urban landscape.1 These are some concepts to emerge from a recent project on psychogeography which then went on to be developed into a series of graphic images to visually communicate the theories:
  • What is the lived space vs the conceived space?
  • What is the reality vs the idea?
  • Educate the idealisers- architects, town planners, lawyers etc. Help them to become more aware of the effects of their decisions in the world.
  • Each man and woman should be aware that they are an active agent in configuring the city space, through tactical behaviour which exists outside of that which fits into the schema of administration.
  • Practice detournement on signage.
  • Look forstrange, unexpected usage and create situations.
  • Become hyper observant.
  • Talk to people about place and their experience.
  • What is real and what is fake?
  • What is simulacra and what organically emerged?
  • Remove all constraints and then you can do anything you want.
  • Become a true ecologist of all things.
  • What is the proper?
  • Use a journey as a way of remembering.
  • What are the multiple possibilities of use?
  • What is fiction, what is fact? Reverse them.
  • Go for a walk.
  • Go to places you shouldnt.
  • Be a critique of social space.
  • See the ludicrous.
  • How would an alien see it?
  • Comment, critique and reflect on your surroundings How do you see / understand the city?
  • Alter your consciousness.
  • Move out of the flow.
  • Go with the flow.
  • What is the mental space of the physical space?
  • Enhance and amplify your experience.
  • Learn by moving.
  • Which bits of the city are computer generated?
  • Break the habits and routine of movement and behaviour.
  • What are the alternatives to the guidebook suggestions (and the laws)?
  • Tear out some pages of the guidebook (and the lawbook).
  • Cover over some areas of the map.
  • Dont avoid experiences (or do).
  • Draw a qualitative or emotion map.
  • Become more conscious of place.
  • Dont base your decisions on the preconceptions or the idea but rather on your experience.
You can buy the book here Psychogeography (Pocket Essentials) Endnotes 1. Wikipedia Entry on Psychogeography - Available at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychogeography - Accessed 2011 The Open Wilderness Guiding Bookfor city explorers available to buy from Amazon.

item.title: Drawing
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Drawing is a tool which can be used in a multitude of contexts. The act of drawing is usually done alone although people in a group can draw each other or collaborate activities could take place. In relation to design, drawing can be used for:

Ideation

Drawing as a tool for coming up with and mashing together ideas. One example of this would be a kind of 'automatic' drawing but with the subject matter in mind. The design brief might be to do with designing a new kind of mobile architecture for cities. The drawer may keep in mind the city location, movement, structure, dwelling, habitation, dwellers and these themes can be mixed with freely associated ideas which come during the drawing process. Specific objects and ontological contexts can be included into the drawing- e.g. a football, and then perhaps the systemic structures associated with the football's construction, use, purchase, raw material extraction, manufacturer. These other ideas can feed in like adding ingredients to a recipe.

Observation

Drawing can be used to observe a location, context, object, and / or activity in detail. The drawer has to concentrate on the subject matter to create the drawing and so looks in more detail than they may normally do.

Creating prototypes

Drawing can be used to sketch to develop ideas. Drawing can construct a narrative. It is something which requires dedication and time to practice and therefore a story unfolds over time whether it is an improvement in the drawing skills or looking ever closer at and around the subject matter. [caption id="attachment_560" align="alignnone" width="614"] Santa Muerta Mask - Drawing by Andy Welch[/caption] Drawing is something which I often find surprising. Perhaps I will begin doodling without anyrational reason or predefined ideaand by the end of the doodle, when I have filled the page, I will be surprised by how much meaning can be extracted from the image, or how an image of thoughts, information, knowledge I couldn't consciously stitch together in language is created.

item.title: Dieter Rams - Design Principles
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_563" align="alignnone" width="280"] Dieter Rams[/caption] 1. Good Design is innovative It does not copy existing product forms, nor does it produce any kind of novelty for the sake of it. The essence of innovation must be clearly seen in all functions of a product. The possibilities in this respect are by no means exhausted. Technological development keeps offering new chances for innovative solutions. 2. Good Design makes a product useful A product is bought in order to be used. It must serve a defined purpose in both primary and additional functions. The most important task of design is to optimise the utility of a product. 3. Good Design is aesthetic The aesthetic quality of a product and the fascination it inspires is an integral part of the its utility. Without doubt, it is uncomfortable and tiring to have to put up with products that are confusing, that get on your nerves, that you are unable to relate to. However, it has always been a hard task to argue about aesthetic quality, for two reasons. Firstly, it is difficult to talk about anything visual, since words have a different meaning for different people. Secondly, aesthetic quality deals with details, subtle shades, harmony and the equilibrium of a whole variety of visual elements. A good eye is required, schooled by years and years of experience, in order to be able to draw the right conclusion. 4. Good Design helps a product be understood It clarifies the structure of the product. Better still, it can make the product talk. At best, it is self-explanatory and saves you the long, tedious perusal of the operating manual. 5. Good Design is unobtrusive Products that satisfy this criterion are tools. They are neither decorative objects nor works of art. Their design should therefore be both neutral and restrained leaving room for the users self-expression. 6. Good Design is honest An honestly-designed product must not claim features it does not have being more innovative, more efficient, of higher value. It must not influence or manipulate buyers and users. 7. Good Design is durable It is nothing trendy that might be out-of-date tomorrow. This is one of the major differences between well-designed products and trivial objects for a waste-producing society. Waste must no longer be tolerated. 8. Good Design is thorough to the last detail Thoroughness and accuracy of design are synonymous with the product and its functions, as seen through the eyes of the user 9. Good Design is concerned with environment Design must contribute towards a stable environment and a sensible use of raw materials. This means considering not only actual pollution, but also the visual pollution and destruction of our environment. 10. Good Design is as little design as possible Back to purity, back to simplicity. If you want to go further in depth about the man, his history and design ethos then buy this book As Little Design As Possible: The Work of Dieter Rams

item.title: Pat Burt's Web Design Tips
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Contrast

If you observe any design principle and completely forget about the others, observe contrast. Contrast is the difference between two elements; the more difference there is, the more contrast there is. Here are some elements you can use to boost contrast:
  • Big elements and small elements
  • Light colors and dark colors
  • Serif (Times New Roman, Georgia) and Sans-serif (Arial, Verdana) typefaces
  • Thick and thin (bold and normal, thick lines and thin lines)

Negative Space

Its not uncommon for amateurs or clients to want to fill up the space on a design. They often see negative (or white) space as unused potential. You need to explain to them that viewers need space to breathe to not feel over-burdened when looking at your website. Good places to throw in negative space include thick margin, bigger spaces between headers, and space around your wordmark (logo) for it to breathe.

Balance

Balance is how your website tends to feel when someone looks at it. How about looking at your design and thinking about whether it feels lop-sided? One thing to note is that you can have an asymmetrical design and still have balance, occasionally, it depends on your content or navigation on the right side to balance out heavy graphics on the left. Some things you can do to help balance your website are to determine how youll be aligning images in your content section and to center your website horizontally on the page.

Repetition

Repetition can be used to describe the repetition of design elements. This can be through the repetition of specific graphics, line widths, general shapes, etc. Its also worth noting that Repetition and Contrast need to be balanced effectively to truly have a great design.

Proximity

Proximity refers to the distance between design elements. One of my teachers said it best when she said: If youre going to move it there, either dont do it at all, or go all the way. If design elements (or anything for that matter) are too close together, it creates a tension spot that makes it unconsciously uncomfortable to look at. Allow me to illustrate my example. You have the following 3 images, each with 2 elements. One of these is uncomfortable to look at. Can you guess which one? If you guessed the first one, youre right. The tight spots between the objects and the border create tension for the viewer.

Unity

Unity is how well your website appears as a single unit. With Content Management Systems (CMS) being the new hot web item, its not uncommon to exercise unity across your website or on a single page. A good guideline to follow is that if you can slice through your website (anywhere) and both results look entirely different from each other, you might have a problem worth addressing.

Focal Point

Your website needs a focal point just as much as a print ad needs one. When a newcomer looks at your website and has a feeling that hes direction-less, chances are, hell be navigating to a different site where hell have visual direction. Contrast plays a big role in creating a focal point through the use of big images and big headers. Also, this is harder to explain, but if your line flow generally points to the same element on your website, that helps in creating a focal point. Here are some visual examples that help illustrate what I mean: Thats all for applying design principles to web design. But here are 3 additional tips. :)

Originality

Theres something to be said about originality, you will get noticed. By no means do I mean you should blatantly avoid design principles because you want to be a pioneer, but try to design something new, something original. If that doesnt work out, the most youll have lost is your time, but if it does work out, it can me a whole lot more website visitors or a whole lot more clients.

Love what you do

Like any other job or hobby, you need to truly love what it is you do. If you dont have a passion for web design, itll show in your work. If you simply dont care what the client thinks or wants, itll show in your work.

Never Stop Learning

Web Design, like many other types of design, has fads. You may be the type of person that wouldnt touch a fad with a ten foot pole, but even if you wont do that, you still need to understand why its a fad and why its working for a lot of people right now. This book is well regarded to further your knowledge about web design HTML & CSS: Design and Build Web Sites

item.title: Story Cubes
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This method can be done alone or in a group. Construct a simple schematic for a cube, like so: Create a number of these, say four, and choose a context of a school. You could make each cube a classroom for a different subject or do a different building structure: e.g. the gym, the art studio, the music theatre. Then on each side of the cube draw a different activity which you associate with the room. Take the completed cubes and construct narratives by mixing cubes from different people or mixing cubes from different sub-context together e.g. mix the geography subject cube with the maths subject cube to create new subjects or mix the gym cube with the art studio cube.
