item.title: Self-Shot Travel Filmmaking Manifesto
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
1. Formulate complete sentences when speaking into the camera
  2. Keep the audience in mind with what you say to the camera
  3. The camera is not a confidant. Use your diary for that.
  4. If you are going to do a travelling shot. Make it worthwhile.
  5. Dont shoot unless you are interested in what you are shooting.
  6. Dont try and be a presenter.
  7. Dont try to shoot Nat Geo documentaries.
  8. Dont describe, observe and shoot (unless its a video diary).
  9. If you are shooting your own face, make sure your face is in the shot.
  10. Keep soundbites down to under 10 seconds. Keep dialogue down to 10 shots of 10 seconds per piece. Keep complicated reflections for the written journal.
  11. Look into the camera when you are talking into it.
  12. Dont say a place is beautiful, amazing, I am in awe of it. Instead shoot it.
  13. Relax.
  14. Learn from your mistakes.
  15. Get close to the action.
  16. Use a tripod when possible.
  17. Let people speak if they want.
  18. Whatever is the central subject matter- if it is a an object- get plenty of good shots of it. Less is more.
  19. If you are shooting something with a name for research, get the name written down.

item.title: Simplify Manifesto
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I wrote this post last winter (2010). Subsections are updates winter 2011 in retrospect. I am going to be getting rid of things
  • My laptop died and Im resisting the desire to buy another one. Instead, I am using Macs at uni and other machines for work. This has I think had a positive effects on my life the last couple of months. Because it was; creating a place where I could be to be organising files and things. Restricting my productivity due to not being able to run heavy duty apps like Indesign and Lightroom, and generally providing too many opportunities to fiddle due to its portability- I pity those with iPhones.
Reducing the stuff that I do
  • I have stopped actively looking for website work and instead tend to do very specialised work on other projects with other people. This is partly due to experience gained from working before and also from contacts gained through my course.
  • Being in London I have tried to grasp the reality that I cant be doing mountain adventures all the time, so Im not romanticising about them. Instead I have turned my attention to psychogeography stuff, walking and cycling in the city, urban exploring, history and place.
Killing off projects
  • I have come to an appreciation that ideas are cheap and plentiful, not all are worth pursuing and realising a good idea requires time, dedication and effort. Its impossible to realise all the ideas that I have and I wouldnt want to anyway.
Roughing it more
  • I do this by deliberately doing Couchsurfing in the city and other forms of non-standard city accommodation. My life became more difficult, I had to put effort into everyday things like sleeping and eating but it was satisfying. However, a level of stability is important. Finding the right balance isnt easy. Getting too comfortable results in laziness.
Eating less
  • I make my everyday life so that it requires more effort and I didnt have the chance to spend time snacking in a flat. I am eating well, but have a life that requires the energy.
Denaturalising my technological instincts
  • I did a U-turn on this one. Instead I stay aware of the call of technology and have plenty of downtime. On the other hand I am going in deeper with technology and trying out new things like mobile technology, working on macs, GPS, materials, biomimicry, coding, design research.
Making tactile objects instead of digital based media
  • I have done research on craftsmanship through my university course and I have written an essay on the value of knowledge gained through experience. I am yet to do enough making though, and this is coming up in a project where I am looking at artist Daniel McNett.
Spending more time with people talking, cooking, making fires, walking.
  • I am spending more time with people these days because I am there with people.

item.title: Writing Manifesto
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
1. Get up early in the morning to write. e.g. 6 am. I tried writing late at night and got into a counter-productive routine of falling asleep at 10.30 pm, waking up at 2 am and working for a couple of hours maybe thats your ideal time to write. But Ive found the morning to be best for me.
  2. Give yourself the chance to write the crap first draft. I was listening to a podcast by Merlin from 43folders.com. Talking about productivity + being afraid of not having the ability to succeed he spoke of an author who always gives herself this chance, and then from that she might craft it down and only use a tiny fraction of the original draft, but in order to get it all out she doesnt restrict herself. No matter what you will write, youll have to go back and do lots of crafting and editing.
  3. Keep a really tidy workplace with good lighting, no distractions (and no alternative things that can easily be ventured into).
  4. Music. Im very fussy with what I listen to when I write. Some things have been working and some not. For example, Chopins piano sonatas, Vangeliss soundtrack to Antarctica, Igor Stravinsky- The Firebird, Mike Oldfields Music of the Spheres is perfect and Hans Zimmers The Last Samurai soundtrack. If it goes a little bit too epic, cheesy, choral, floral, frenetic, catchy or whatever then it starts to be distracting.
  5. Read, read, read. Im presently reading A Walk in the Mountains of Georgia by Tony Anderson.
  6. Take notes and keep a detailed journal whilst you travel. I kept a journal throughout my journey so far. Its been absolutely vital for remembering details. From reading it back, it triggers further memories, and Im able to weave the storyline. Its an incredibly rewarding experience as I am able to research further into stories and information I noted at the time- like retracing the route.
  7. Look at photos and video. I took a lot of photos so far and the podcasts that were produced at the beginning were brilliant for taking me right back to the moment and what I was thinking and feeling. They have been very useful for writing. After all, a picture tells a thousand words.
  8. Dont try to do too much at once. I write for a maximum of 2.5 hours. Im normally writing from 6.30am to 8.30am. But it depends on the individual.
  9. A rest is good. Sometimes its good to take a couple of days off and come back to your writing really refreshed and enthusiastic.
  10. Sometimes its good to plough on. On the contrary, I find it sometimes good to force myself to keep writing, because sometimes you might be being over critical, over analysing. For me, it takes me a short while to get into the zone, so I try to suspend judgement and keep writing until Im sure I am going to stop.

item.title: Interview Subversive Cartography
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an epic interview I did recently with Charles Denby, Geography student from Kings College, London. What do you think maps do?
I think they can make people see places differently. The maps Im interested in are not necessarily maps that are tools to get from A to B but tools for getting lost or maps that provide routes around your local area. It doesnt really matter about the scale actually. Its about getting off the main roads, taking the side roads and going places people wouldnt normally go.
Thats kinda where the Wandermap stuff comes in in terms of the work that I have done. I would say my travels by bike created a desire to make the traveling experience better by changing where we went. Rather than sticking on a big road you take a smaller road even though it would be slower. Even in Mongolia, for example where there are no roads and it was possible to go anywhere theoretically, it wouldnt make much sense to go there and speed quickly across the map. It wouldnt make a lot of sense to do that. Do you think maps can be useful means of communication?
It would be nice if they could be used more for that purpose. They are used in a lot of places like the London Underground map as an example. They are used to make complicated information more understandable. There are maps that represent networks. In design research you might map out ideas. There is a paper called 'The Reservoir' by one of my tutors, that is about mapping out areas of interest that form islands with open water in between them. The open water represents possibilities. Its about finding new and interesting connections and ideas.
Mapping is a huge area; almost as huge as language. We are living in an age where mapping could come into its own. One of the main reasons for that is the internet, communication technology and computers. We are so used to the printed page being reproduced but there is massive potential for organizing and representing information in different and unique ways.
New ways to read for example. How is reading evolving? You have Kindles and such devices that are remaking the printed page in a digital form. I went to a talk yesterday by a guy called Richard Stallman who had a lot to do with inventing the free software movement and the birth of Linux, the free operating system. He was talking about DRM 'digital rights management' or 'digital handcuffs' as he put it. Buying things through iTunes with the iPod or books bought from Amazon with your kindle restricts your freedom through DRM. That's not good for mapping because it locks the way people access and consume information in a particular way because its dictated by Amazon. Do you think maps have the power to inform or deceive?
The map is not the territory. Youve heard those stories of (people) taking their Iphone into the wilderness and expecting to be able to use it to navigate. They dont get signal and need to be rescued. So its a question of the uses of technologies and the possibilities that people expect to get from technology with mapping capability. Perhaps there are unintended deceptions happening like deliberately (or unconsciously) mapping things in a particular way or viewing a particular geography in a way that directs you into a particular way of acting, which may not be in positive way. Its about what you 'dont know that you know'. Do you think maps can challenge you to think about the world in a different way?
Yeah, my work has been influenced by the Situationists and their 'Theory of the Derive'. They primarily walked and created a activism and architectural theory through community and action that worked from the ground up (from a different type of society). Maps influence the way people move. Architectural blueprints are maps that plan space and locks people into ways of moving. Maps serve as a plan for the world. One kind of mapping is rational and deterministic and another is qualitative and psychological. The bias has been to the former in recent history. What maps did you use before you went on your travels?
I have different approaches for planning navigation for a a trip. Take Mongolia, I looked at online maps such as Google maps and Google earth. I know that Im not going to get all the information I need from the internet so I bought a paper map from Stanfords; a good map of Mongolia . I had a GPS which didnt have any roads on it but it did have towns so at least when we got lost we could move in the direction of a town.
The thing that we noticed when using a GPS was that we didnt ask people for directions so much. We relied on it and developed tunnel vision due to the perceived security offered by the device. The computer says its here so it must be here, so why isnt it there? So we ended up getting frustrated about it rather than using some other approach. We were caught up in trying to master the technology. That is how it might have got in the way. Asking people for directions was another way to open up other opportunities so being invited into peoples yurts or going in an unusual direction. Do you think those maps made you think about Mongolia in a different way?
I dont really think they made me think of Mongolia in any other way. I had a sense of the route in my head. It was never anything other than an idea of a route. Having a route and doing a route are very different things. We cycled 5 days on the open steppe and it was flat and boring so we changed our minds and went to the mountains because it was more challenging. We started off with the map but then we continued based on the reality of the experience. The map is a starting point, its good in that sense. Everyone needs a starting point (and a truthful and reliable one at that). Thats a question of education. How do you think what you have produced is different to other types of maps?
Wandermap started off as a way to approach a particular place in London: Lincoln Inns Fields. It was to 'disrupt the proper' of the space, in order to navigate it in a different way. I was interested in the Derive and that influenced how I would approach that space. I envisaged people could go for a walk with a simple altered map. For example, most of the map was hidden so the map was literally only the starting point.
Then to get over the existential problem of having no structure, simple common geometric shapes are draw in to navigate the space. Its not anything special but I was surprised by the results. It was a nice experience to walk with people and have them see their local place in a different and creative way. As we went along, I had them make drawings and observations, I asked them a series of questions and they would make lists of things that caught their eye along the route. I analyzed their emotions. I have some background in website development so I made an experimental tool in Actionscript. The application allows people to draw on it. However it wasnt where I wanted to go with the project. It felt like a dead end because it seemed too rigid in the way that it worked.
After doing a few maps I was encouraged to keep progressing with the ideas. I had a good idea of the overall theories and concepts so I put that into images and displayed it at end of year show. I put together a manual which said how to do a derive (these walks). A toolkit that extends it further may form my final project. The overall aim is to live adventurously and understand what it means to be free. A manual, tool kit, manifesto and a practice to actively do it - to bring together the philosophy and the practice.
a guidebook coming soon
Why did you pick Lincoln Inn Fields?
It was in a list that the lecturers proposed. I did a lot of research into it. It was interesting how the lawyers played a large part in creating the 'proper', whereas for a while in the same space you had homeless people living there who subverted the law during the 90s. They got kicked out by the lawyers for being unsightly.
This behaviour has a history. Beside the square is the Royal College of Surgeons. Back in 1800 they used to bring dead bodies there to be dissected and the lawyers didnt like that. They were going for a nice walk and someone was bringing a dead body past- not a good look. It was all to do with keeping the sense of 'proper' and order; their idea of it.
The homeless now have an understanding with the wardens that they have to be away by six in the morning in order to keep up appearances. After a while you wonder what the purpose really is. It serves a purpose to have order so people can go about to carry out their activities and that order emerged out of a perhaps more (in some way) disorderly situation. There were reports about the area being rife with petty crime.
That was important in the past but now people are used to behaving in a particular way and having discretion and tolerance for other people. I dont advocate that government should be taking away all of a sudden because its what structures everyones reality. It would be like the summer riots without the fire services. Those that are categorised as 'out' of the system and are actively 'disavowed' or ignored suddenly appear in a very real way.
Architecture structurally informs the hierarchy and order within that system. Architecture is in a quandry, torn between its essence and what is in demand. When other areas develop so fast (the largely immaterial network technologies for example) there is a conflict in reality between the opportunities offered by the communication technologies and the infrastructure. It becomes obvious when you understand it. Mapping is a way to make these discontinuities, absurdities clear and real and gets conversations going to form new ideas and movements. How do you think youre different as a cartographer?
I wouldnt really see myself as a cartographer. Its more an area of interest that I have got. I have looked at the work of other people such as Katherine Harman; a book with a lot of qualitative mapping called You Are Here. Thats one area that I really like. There is another book called "Else/Where".
I like the data visualization stuff; "Information is Beautiful" by David McCandless. He seems to have a monopoly on that. There is 'Newsmap' which visualises news from Google news. Google news is not a good place to go for news and (I know) from experience. There was a war in Georgia and I was a bit worried whether I would be able to go back there. I got addicted to stories about Georgia. My point being, its amazing to watch how different news stories take different standpoint but seem to end up contradicting each other.
There is a space to create something that balances the news up. There is a news site in London called Indymedia, run by the protestors and activists. What was the question, oh yeah, other mapping? I have been influenced by other people on my course. A guy did a book, which is left in the library and people navigate by finding the places in the photos.
I really like Luces stuff, we get on really well. I like the way she is interested in narratives through maps and journeys. For example, doing a journey and recording your perceptions of time whilst walking up a hill. Time is an important question at the moment with technology and this obsession with speed.
I went to Dubai for work last year. I dont fly often. I still find it astonishing to climb into that elongated room and sit in a cramped seat for seven hours watching rubbish films and then be 8,000 miles away. I think it is really important to not lose sight of how weird that is. Psychologically it is problematic. There are people who are deal with the question of speed like Paul Virillio; an urbanist and social theorist. Mapping is a question of time aswell as space. Time is to do with relative motion so time is to do with mapping. A map is precursor to moving or acting at some point. That is the whole point of it. Do you think that your map is trying to subvert other maps?
There are two futures. One future is a predictable future is an increment of what came before and the other future is the unpredictable future and that is the real future. I would say that time fits into both these categories. There is one type of time which is incremental and predictable; the time that you set on your watch which is in chunks. Its nice to think that's how time works. You know how much time you have in your life and therefore you can have a schedule or a calendar. You can fill it with spectacle and activities or whatever you like.
The thing is that by looking at time in that way is silly because it means you are not respecting the other kind of time. The other kind of time is about how you perceive time which is a serious matter. It is always a balance between the two... You get these Indians guys, mediating and having infinite time. Its because they have a completely different view of time. Its easy to say scientifically that doesn't make any sense but that is because the science only sees things in terms of the quantifying technology. Modern technology and modern physics are all about quantifying things although in fact is it still trying to find the meaning and nature of things; even quantum physics. If you could describe yourself as a cartographer how would you describe yourself?
Maybe a cartographer is a way of being. Have you heard the phrase 'footage for footage'? You walk and then you get a narrative from the walking so you get a journey in your memory and you can write a story about it. You can take photos and you can make a gallery exhibition and you can do a video about it. I'm talking about someone who is a cross between a cartographer, walker, adventure, photographer, observer, philosopher, archivist, writer. Instead of writing in prose why not be writing in maps- a language of maps? Structure stories as maps. What do you think a cartographers role is in society?
I think it has a lot to do with the way that people move and the way that people access information. There is a lot of power for whoever is creating the maps and for whoever is getting the cartographer to make the map. This is because you can structure the way that people move and the way they structure information.
A website and is a kind of map because it structures the way that people access content. You can privilege some information over others. You have to be careful. Its worthwhile keeping a good eye on how maps are used for controlling (this can stretch to architecture, or town planning, or even the design of the Olympic Games stadium). Its about being responsible. There are cartographers that make maps in service of what already exists and those that make maps that reflect and comment on the path. What attracted you to make maps with doodles?
When I was travelling, I came to the realization that if I wanted to have a good travel(life) experience, it didnt matter where I went, but it mattered that I went to places that took me out of my comfort zone and that it is different for everyone. Its also about breaking routine patterns of thinking and movement. What impacts have your travelling on your life?
The ideas of my travels area always entering back into my life. A map is a medium of communicating information in a particular way or its about encouraging people to act in a particular way so for me Im trying to pass on information to other people that might benefit them. What did you choose to use Google maps as your base map for your Flash tool?
Its my limits as a programmer. Flash has only a Google Maps API available. Im not a brilliant programmer, its not my forte. Why did you use terrain view as the default?
It was the clearest, most uncluttered one for my purpose. Ideally the map would be able to focus into a location and choose ways to alter the map from a library of stuff that the community had contributed. You would be able to put different shapes and pictures of stuff over it, old maps over the top of it. You would be able to mess around with Google maps, so it just showed waterways, or alleys. Do you think there is anything subversive about the maps that you make?
I would say that they are a different way of thinking about maps. There are a lot of people happy with their lives, but some people are dissatisfied with their lives and want to make a change. I felt like that and decided to go on a cycle tour and see where I ended up. It evolved from there because other people were involved. Very soon the thing becomes collaborative. The 'map' of the idea gets completely out of control and impossible to keep a handle on.
My inspiration for travelling came from a dissatisfaction of doing same thing day after day in an IT job . I made a decision and acted on it, which was the most difficult part. Then you realize that the reality of carrying out an idea is different from the original idea. Some people want to do journeys to get around the world the fastest. They sacrifice the experience for the sake of the idea, which is very much a particular mentality of doing something and not the only way. Have you ever challenged authority in any way?
I question things that don't seem to make sense and acting is not the same as talking, writing, thinking, planning. Do you think its had an connection with your life and your maps?
The maps are a starting point for getting ideas into a structure or project. Its a collaborative medium, a way to show information in a structure way. How do you think a map is a good way of visualizing information?
Mapping is something you can do collaboratively. It links to drawing, which is something I love and something that I should do more of. Maps and drawing link together in an inventing process, that is always about a group of people inventing something. Im not really getting anywhere with this question. Do you know any other map makers personally?
Luce. I enjoy visiting the Royal Geographical Society. A friend has been working on mapping Caribbean nature reserves. Is there any that have particularly inspired you?
My tutors, Terry Rosenberg is very interested in drawing and Psychogeography. Iain Sinclair. Are you aware of organizations such as OSM?
Yeah I did a website for an organisation that mapped Georgia for OSM. I used an OSM map of Asia just recently when I went from velomap.org. Are you aware of any other groups?
There is a that ludocity.org. Look up Placehacking. The stuff they do is amazing. There is this whole dirty side to the city this whole ditry murky sort of grimy underbelly and London is great for that and thats a fascinating area. The Situationists envisaged being able to run over the top of buildings. There is power structure to do with 'access'. Only rich people can go onto to the top of buildings and see stuff and get the fancy views from a penthouse or restaurant (or can they). So the whole thing is about subverting maps and envisioning cities of the future as well as seeing the world differently and learn to make the leap and 'act' in whatever form that may take.

item.title: Saving the World Through the Derive
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
----- Edit 29/04 ----- Psychogeography is essentially using walking as a way to build energy and to meditate on spaces.The consequence of this is that the city will become more of a part of you and you will have some kind of energy. Observation in general can be done to observe reaction to surroundings, not for the case of theorising, but for improving the city so that it becomes a learning tool that leads people onto the path to liberation and freedom. It should work to raise their consciousness. It is possible to observe what kind of consciousness exists in the city: e.g. a logic of doing or logic in general. The derive is the starting point that breaks a pattern of thought, value or belief system; e.g. agitates and destroys idealogy resulting in the individual to become open to new experience and learning - that allows them to make progress on their path to freedom. A It is a recognition that the world is not made of good and evil, black and white, rather it is all 'holy' per se and can be observed as such. Different levels of consciousness exist- some lead nowhere and some lead to the path of liberation. Liberation, briefly is freedom from desire, the body and material elements and living in bliss. It is the path of enlightenment. It is the answer to all issues involved in human subjective realities. Observation and awareness, living each moment as opposed to theories, ideas and living in thoughts, not being present, are the key to becoming closer to 'The Real' or 'god' (not any particular god or affiliation) and creating heaven on earth which is the ultimate aim. ------ End edit ------
I am interested in psychogeography which emerged naturally through my bike travels. Cycle touring can be boring if you focus only on the destination. By looking ahead to the next place, you forget to look sideways. Social theorist and urbanist, Paul Virilio said that speed causes loss of lateral vision so think this in terms of high speed transport.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=JtCL0bnqxpQ
As humans shape their tools, the tools shape them. This applies to any kind of tool from a drill to a computer to transport and architecture. The way you do things prefigures how you approach new problems and the space you occupy shapes your thinking.
Tools that allow us to go faster make us look ahead to the end faster. In a car, we need to keep control and to cope with other cars coming fast towards us. In thinking terms, this is similar to vertical versus logical thinking. Vertical thinking is a strategy with logical steps to reach an imagined end goal. Each step has to work to go to the next one.
The world is complex, with a huge amount of variables and it doesnt work in rational, logical way only. Nature is what is known as a first order cybernetic system. It looks unpredictable but after a while you see trends. Humans are second order cybernetic organisms; and able to be unpredictable. Some humans act predictably, some dont, each behaviour has its place and there is a dialectic between the two.
If you know the book Lateral Thinking by Edward De Bono, you know that he makes the point that lateral thinking provides ways to solve a problem, make progress or movement, other than rational logical steps, and he says that both ways of thinking are needed. Similarly in this paper, Terry Rosenberg talks of the Apollonians (rational thinkers) and the Dionysians (artists-types), and centrepetal(vertical) and centrafugal(lateral) ideation techniques except with more spatial metaphors. The centrepetal is symbolised by a channel of thought in a particular direction and the centrefugal is a associative process with many paths leading in directions without destination.
Speed increasingly locks society into progresses in technological increments and a well-worn channel of movement. Rosenberg in his paper said that, in terms of design thinking, this is likely to lead to hackneyed research, and in terms of society or the human race, what? Ever increasing speed, Paul Virilio and Slavoj Zizek both agree is leading towards a singularity or an endpoint, whatever that is
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ShJiiMqEsgA&feature=player_embedded
This forms part of the foundation for my concern that moving slowly and looking around, is important.
The inspiration for wandering came initially from my travels, taking the small rather than the main roads and picking up the lateral thinking book which suggests ways to repattern thinking. I found de Bonos book difficult to read and not particularly useful itself, but, it helped to consolidate changes in my travel approach towards following the divergent courses of opportunity that arise along the way as well as having a big idea of going from A-B. As I mentioned before both are needed, the idea as well as a healthy amount of diverging but still returning to a main course. The main idea may have been affected by the divergence.
More recently, during my uni studies, I was introduced to psychogeography and the ideas of the Situationists, which are mostly city-centric. These are ground level disrupting movements and tapping the complexity of the city space for inspiration and quality of experience as well as if necessary a critique of the space for evaluation, for example, for town planning or architecture Im interesting in this but more so in adventure and learning side of things. The thought of turning up in an unknown city and wandering is thrilling, however, I think that the wandering derive technique of the situationists works even better when it is introduced to somewhere who is familiar with their surroundings and has a set routine to break from temporarily to gain insight into the routine.
The idea of the derive and logical versus lateral thinking metaphor stretches to many areas:
* There is the derive at the journey level: diverting from the planned course whilst keeping that planned course as the gravitional and directional pull. * idea level: vertical thinking and lateral thinking * society level: technological incremental progress versus . (perhaps reflexive versus reflective) and this also works at the strategic planning level. Strategic versus tactical action (vis a vis Michel De Certeau Practice of Everyday Life)? * evolutionary progress: Genetic homogeniety versus genetic diversity. | normal transmission of trait versus mutatation * education: logical thinking, versus exploratory learning * city level: getting from A to B as efficiently as possible versus wandering aimlessly * communication level: debating culture ideas versus lived experience * experience: imagined object versus experienced state * flow: broken flow versus in the flow state * speed: slowly versus fast * consciousness direction: Inner versus outer reflection * respons-ability: Reflex versus reflection * music: traditional versus jazz / avant garde
How do these ideas get put into practice. Some, like the city level are easy whereas most are intertwined with constraints of perception and go back to the fact that we are shaped by our tools (think society as a tool) as we have shaped them. Humans have the ability to act unpredictably. Organisms monitor their own homeostasis. Humans are autopoetic e.g. we structure the conditions for our own survival. So, In order to survive we need a collaborative retooling process. Tools that help to see the world differently. City level wandering is not costly and reaps great rewards in improvement of experience. Author Iain Sinclair is well known for using such techniques in his research. Derive and derive thinking are unknowingly or knowingly put into practice by many other journalists, explorers and adventurers, educators etc. Some specialised roles employ either logical or lateral more than others. If we look at society what are the most prolific roles, and what kind of people to they create? How does the economy shape the people? Once it comes to the stage of putting an idea into practice, it comes to the stage to proliferate the idea, make it ones consciousness and awareness and bring it into everyday life. This requires a self-observation in order to know where to act as well as what there is available to act on. For a busy professional with little time during the day, these ideas may form a wander at lunch or in the evening, or journeys on holidays or weekends, or they might come as different ways to approach problem solving. If both the driving idea and the centrefugal movements are needed then who is providing the driving idea? Where are the driving ideas coming from. Where is the connection to the space of engagement? What are the movements required to navigate to the space of engagement. I think that it is important to keep in mind the need for both types of thinking as well as how this is unavoidably connected to the tools we use and spaces we inhabit.

item.title: Support Structures, Forays, Obsessions
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
-----Edit 29/04----- Travel is seeing outside of the reality of the national you were brought up in. It can also be experience, but generally experience doesn't matter where you are, rather it matters what is going on in your head. Observing everything as neither good or bad just 'is', leads to less judging which is anyway relative to limitations of subjective values and belief structures and level of consciousness, which leads to bringing of experience, which leads to growth. A support structure in general is something that reduces the reliance on material elements but also supports the body and path to moksha. It supports the body as much as that individual requires according to their level of consciousness. This is the work required by the individual and the individual should know what they need as opposed to just consuming a dictated support structure from government or lifestyle marketing. In general what is more important is meeting people that are more enlightened than yourself rather than creating a material support structure without resources going to the transformation path. Obsessions are just intense concentrations required to achieve work to provide necessary conditions. Obsession is intense concentration. Intense concentration comes from practicing attention through techniques. ----- End Edit------
What is travel if not a geographical way to break up routines of movement and be opened up to unfamiliar environments, people, places, objects and networks?
Anyone who feels like they want to experience the world more directly as it really is as opposed to just a world within a world; the private flat, the office world, the bar, the coffee shop, the infrastructure of a holiday resort created for leisure, a package adventure holiday, the business world, will need to create a vehicle and support structure for themselve; a mental and physical support structure that allows them to exist outside of existing and preceding structure, perhaps albeit temporarily. Changing your world will feel strange and take effort.
If you spend a significant amount of time reading the mainstream news, watching television or playing online games then you might need to rearrange how you use your time.
However, taking the example of playing an online game, I was recently in contact with a Couchsurfer who had been a professional poker player and had gone on a journey to find a particular unusually successful and young player and then written about the experience.
His interest lead him to make the journey. Being driven to take action, to research and travel to study an aspect of culture may allow you to connect with others who have similar obsessional interest and curiosity.
If travel is to get away from people then you will always find people in the strangest places and failing that certainly be in contact with nature, possibly not in the most favourable way such as the fate of Alexander Supertramp in Into the Wild. However, if he had been a little better prepared then he may have survived.
Anyone who wants to experience the world can take a walk without a purpose through a city, perhaps from East to West or following a river or a geographical feature rather than for the common reason for travel; to get from A to B. If you want to explore outside of the support structures that already exist then you need to be prepared whether that is, with the walk example, by talking warm clothes, a rucksack, food, water and a destroyed map or assembling a more complex trip.
Existing interests, even distractions can be turned around to create meaningful pursuits if approached in a critically reflective way or forming a well considered program of investigation that requires interaction with people, objects and networks out there in the world.

item.title: The Mixture of Play and Adventure
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Play is intrinsic to the human condition.
Play is defined as:
Voluntary, intrinsically motivated activities normally associated with recreational pleasure and enjoyment.
Play engages and allows for unexpected consequences. It uses the brain in ways that are outside of the usual everyday routines. Play on a basic level involves a level of adventurous curiosity in order to do it. Whether that is playing a computer game, a sport, an online game such as blah or a geographical game such as orienteering or hide and seek.
Play is usually but not always part of a game. A game can be something predefined or entirely, creatively and intentionally constructed, which imposes a set of rules which mean that normal behaviour is subverted in order to play and construct the world of the game and become absorbed into it.
In order to play a game, a commitment has to be made to leave cynicism behind and fully engage with the playing discourse. Any good game will transport the player into the alternative reality where the player becomes absorbed for a period of time.
Once the game ends, there is a deep breath and a return to the usual routines of reality accompanied by smiles and a sense of satisfaction.
The seminal text in the field of play studies is Homo Ludens by Johan Huizinga. Huizinga defines play as follows:
Summing up the formal characteristic of play, we might call it a free activity standing quite consciously outside ordinary life as being not serious but at the same time absorbing the player intensely and utterly. It is an activity connected with no material interest, and no profit can be gained by it. It proceeds within its own proper boundaries of time and space according to fixed rules and in an orderly manner. It promotes the formation of social groupings that tend to surround themselves with secrecy and to stress the difference from the common world by disguise or other means.
The social groupings that are formed by play are usually dropped after the end of the game however, often the bonds created through playing the game remains; having worked through a series of challenge and problems and having a sense of interdependence, respect of difference and the players ability to contribute to the progress of the game in different ways; their strengths, weaknesses and reactions to the different emotions, twists and turns as the game progresses.
Games have mechanisms that contribute to the attributes of the gameplay for the players. Behavioral Momentum; the tendency of players to keep doing what they have been doing. Achievements; a virtual or physical representation of having accomplished something. Cascading Information; The theory that information should be released in the minimum possible snippets to gain the appropriate level of understanding at each point during. Discovery; Also called Exploration, players love to discover something, to be surprised. Urgent Optimism; Extreme self motivation. The desire to act immediately to tackle an obstacle combined with the belief that we have a reasonable hope of success.
There are many attributes to games that engage people and a great deal in common between adventure and play. Adventure could be more likely an attribute of the wider scope of ludic behaviour. Games can be invented and developed, played alone or with others, can exist in micro or macro circumstances, and be public or private.
Having grown up with the development of computer games as well as traditional games I see a huge potential for how games can spill between the virtual and real world and how the two can be mixed. Games are also great ways to engage people across cultures and language barriers because often the signs and symbols of the game and simply playing in order to learn can transcend these barriers.

item.title: MACP Course Narrative
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
An overarching logic of the theory and practice behind a year on the Critical Practice Course at Goldsmiths
When I first started the course I was well keen on learning. I was open minded to what the course could do for me. I was skeptical because I had had such a good experience with travelling that I wondered what the city could offer me.
The first project the space project was a confusing but ultimately rewarding one. It was a group project which the group took too with great vigour, being a group split up between eastern and western factions. This meant that everyone felt motivated. Studies conducted at Lincoln's Inn Filed were insightful because of how they seemed frustrating and compromised to me. However, the final project, a map of small printed photos was a great thing to show. And a good way to overcome the problem of limited sight to visualise practices in a space.
I found it difficult to design into the space, having no design practice background, which meant I delved into psychogeography and mapping. I came up with a mapping technique of creating drawn abstract maps which would then be walked with someone else who would annotate and fill in the map. Take away from this would be working with others, walking, drawing, cultural probes are good. Taking too many photos is not good. Don't expect to visualise perfectly your own image of the project in a group project. Coding is frustrating and time consuming if you aren't very good at it. Promotion and marketing of ideas is not my strong point. Whereas conceptualising and testing conceptual ideas with other people I show talent in.
The city space is rich for this kind of walking techniques and destruction and detournement of maps is a rich vein of work.
I read a number of good books at this stage. Most notably Bachellarlds Poetics of Space, Michel De Certeau's Practice of Everyday Life, the Society of the Spectacle etc. I think that reading more practical mapping examples and spending more time on working through the design by testing it would be a good way forward.
Learnt ideas would be that the city doesn't help consciousness. Its acting to barrier protect and channel the populous has the counter productive affect of making them sleepy and apathetic. Walking in the city is an experience in its own right worthy of comparision to anything else you could hope to do. The visible public sphere is very closed in what it gives away in true human behaviour and play. Only spectacles and situations create different modes of behaviour.
The second project Making Making, I drifted around doing research later on back to this later.
I started immediately on the gamification project with Carolin and Joe. This project alighted the struggle of doing a group project but also the huge potential in having good people working together and working through things. It was a journey for me because we spent so long working on and honing the idea, it was frustrating at times. The research seemed to spiral out of control sometimes. However, I did a lot of reading exploring what makes good and bad telologically interaction. I read Dreyfuss' On The Internet about the problems of telelogically meditated interaction, the problem of surfing of always having the chance to find the most interesting thing after the next click. Paul Dourish's Where the Action is was also influential with its demystifying of the nature of how the brain and body do stuff in the world. Most notably that there is no humanculus in the head to speak of looking out and pre empting actions. Somethings you just do unconsciously- e.g. sex, running, walking. Things that you get into the zone with. Some things are naturalised, some become so through doing them.
I was also made away of the wide variety of sharing services and this notion of the sharing economy. Collaborative consumption and that stuff.
In parallel I had a disenchantment with private space, my flat, living conditions and how they were affecting my thinking and behaviour. I found having a private flat to encourage me to spend time alone and afffected my outlook. I experimented with squatting and couchsurfing in the city. This massively improved my quality of life in terms of spendingn time with other people and also threw things into disarrary with regards to stability of being able to wash clothes and such things. However, overall being homeless was much more preferable to having a flat, especially one that I was paying for, defintiely in the short term.
My experiment with squatting also coincided with a discovery of protests and marches like March 30th in London. This generally fuelled a feeling of wondering whether a revolution was imminent in the traditional style. I decided to investgiate it throughg the open product brief. Using actor network theory to explore the 'mesh' of the protest. I took film, photos, audio and interviews and studied all different facitons of the protests from different points of view. I evolved ideas about ways to protest on the streets and also how to design into the protest. Most influential reading at this time was Heidegger's Question Concerning Technology and The Sense of the World Jean Luc Nancy, and most of all watching Youtube videos of Slavoj zizek. I must have watched most of the ones available.
However, after a couple of months of that I decided that the protest space was not the place to design into because it was so easily manipulated by the strategic powers. I had no clue about what to do but in a desperate attempt to create an exhibit for the end of year show I created a series of graphic boards and did a 24 hour micro-adventure around the city. This further explored the ideas of psychogeography but also brought in notions of prepartion, becoming more conscious, becoming aware of the strategic organisations. The need of course is because of looming ecological catastrophe (and power is a simulation) - e.g. the news is a simulation in order to keep the illusion of power.
I enjoyed creating the graphics and knew that they would lead to other things. I hadn't done any work for ages so I took jobs on Tradeshows in Dubai and Abu Dhabi and flew out there for October. I listened to audiobooks by Timothy Morton and Zizek as well as NLP on the laws of attraction which is base level psychology about how to manipulate behaviour based on pre-existing functioning codes of conduct and manipulating senses, emotions and preconceptions.
Dubai was extremely interesting. It was an insight into the capital culture and the project manager. Dubai was a fantastic feat of engineering and entriely constructed culture. Weirdly although it is alive and kicking it feels already like wilderness. Which made me think about how the wilderness is already there. The people are part of the wilderness. I could see into the future. I knew that it would become a ruin but that increased the fun of it in the moment because I knew it would be gone. I also felt like I had a secret no one else knew, but maybe they did.
It was also a slightly mind-numbing experience as I was required to act in accordance with the job specification which was below my full capability but also empowering in the sense that it focussed my energy and attention. The travelling aspect was absolutely brilliant and I would jump on the next plane again to have a similar experience, although it would definitely become boring if not different. You only need to learn that stuff once.
I wrote an essay on Craftsmanship and important books read were Shop Class as Soulcraft and this notion of tacit knowledge vs epistomological knowledge. Which is a subtle difference but unsettling to realise how my own tacit knowledge feels somehow exploded or fragmented by its broadness as well as narrowness because of its digital hardware based often.
During the end of the year I spent a lot of time finishing my book and I started writing the second one. This definitely fed back into my work as the ideas leaked out and were backed up by my studies.

item.title: The crisis of space in the post-concept city and the deriv as a practice-centric research tool
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Andrew Welch The modern concept city is a problematic and complex space which reveals a wealth of practices hidden from view by social norms, regulations and surveillance away from the public into private and between spaces. The tension between the public and the private space is an interesting space for design; in this case through the use of the Situationist-inspired deriv in the city streets. Photographic and tally survey research in Lincoln's Inn Field revealed the most commonly observed practices as walking, talking on a mobile phone, or eating; in other words a visually homogenised and narrow array of practices of individuals who were operating within the realms of what would commonly be considered socially and legally propr. The majority of people were wearing dark coloured blue or black business clothes which are the recognisable 'propr' uniform of the capitalistic working environment. Initially there did not appear to be anything surprising about the observations but this could be due to my familiarity with the culture of context. The feeling is that there is something unusual about the 'normal' behaviour of people but it is problematic if not impossible to identify. Winter conditions may have affected the observed practices but there are other factors which do not encourage play, social ease, performance and creativity. There is an abundance of signage, disparate in visual design and subject, which has the effect of overwhelming the attention and senses and creating a will to 'bracket out' these 'hailing' mechanisms and ignore or become less conscious of them so they have more of an unconscious effect. The signs serve as a reminder of the ubiquitous presence of the laws and regulations governing the city space. Lincoln Inn's Field is surrounded by a tall enclosing fence which creates an ambience of authoritarian control. It was erected to keep homeless people from sleeping there after the space was occupied by them in the early nineties. The flow of people through the space is directed via concrete paths and black metal fences which seem to encourage people to pass through the square rather than rendezvous and interaction[1]. In the centre of the space there is a pavilion which in the past housed a bandstand, since removed. These observations appear to suggest a city-planning strategy concerned with controlling objectified 'flows of people' and maintaining the status quo rather than considering practices and promoting creative use of the space. In addition, the use of the space is not well defined because the focus of visible rules is on what is prohibited, not what is allowed. Lincoln's Inn Field is technically a square and not a park and before it was a square it was agricultural land. When it became a square its prime use was as a picnic spot for lawyers. Looking back at the history of the space, there have been moments of theatre, real human activity and participation but today, perhaps affected by its origin (connected and named after the Law Inn), it exists as a somewhat banal and redundant space that actively inhibits the ability of people to dwell, participate there and utilise it as a public space. Initially I thought that the people whom I observed appeared dehumanised. However, after reading De Certeau on Tactics, I considered that perhaps the human-qualities were hidden from view, reserved for other spaces such as their homes away from the panoptic surveillance mechanisms. Considering the growth of the heterotopic space of the internet, perhaps some of these practices had been migrated to the virtual realm. People may have been escaping to the park to be alone and to close off mentally possibly due to the repressive strength of the propr in the surrounding area or from the propr of the office space which bears a resemblance to Debords theory of the social separation of labour. Chance social meetings between strangers seemed never to occur which appears to be an aspect of the propr. De Certeau writes of tactics employed by users operating under the circumstances of a propr who 'make do' through techniques which 'do not obey the law of the place[2]'. For example, the employee may subvert the power of his employer by giving gifts, working for free, or La perruque (doing his own work under the time of the employer). Tactics are employed in the space of the other (the strategic organisation) and are 'determined by the absence of a propr locus'[3]. Seeking to unveil the location of suppressed human qualities which better obey the heterogeneous nature of human beings we learn from De Certeau of a coping mechanism which cannot be read from visual observations other than by its lack of appearance. From a design point of view, there seems to be a wealth of possibility in searching for, revealing and learning from these hidden practices and in understanding the nature of acting within the strategic system. What caused this kind of tactical behaviour to emerge? De Certeau writes of the view from the World Trade Center. 'If you go up there, you look down like a god, detached from the 'devices of Daedalus' in mobile and endless labyrinths far below'[4]. This metaphor for the viewpoint of the modern city planner is useful because we can get an insight into the idealistic stance taken to imagine the city design. By taking this idealistic stance the practices at street-level are overlooked even though the qualitative knowledge of the city is held by the walkers down below; a criticism of how the modern city fails to considerately accommodate the user. During The Enlightenment there was a move from a feudal to capitalist system of society which categorised practices and the city to rationalise and create order from chaotic city spaces. This was due to a number of factors driven by increases in trade, need for food production and a desire by the professional classes to increase their material standards of living[5]. Evidently there were many benefits to this progression but the categorising is problematic because what does not fit into the categories is 'other' to the system. For example a penal system which define people as either law abiding citizens or criminals. Modern architecture also emerged alongside the modern economic system at this time. The fundamental essence of architecture is in conflict with the interests of politics and cost-cutting budget constraints. De Certeau writes 'The functionalist organisation, by privileging progress causes the condition of its own possibility space itself to be forgotten - space thus becomes the blind spot'[6] because the focus is always on the future, the here of the now is missed. Physical space is flaunted by large corporations manifest in the large atriums which serve as a spectacle. They appear to reinforce an obsession with aspiring to have space for its own sake as an object of desire. From a design point of view, the possibility to reconfigure space in a playful way is something which presents itself an as opportunity within the system. De Certeau writes of the concept city's (as an ideology) decay but that tactical entities have 'reinforced themselves in a proliferating illegitimacy, developed and insinuated themselves into the networks of surveillance'[7]. This development is an insight into how users engage in systems and reinforce them. Users are also the components of the system and hold the potential for reconfiguration such as public sector workers who choose to take political action against the recent austerity cuts by striking, also have a responsibility and opportunity to make changes to the way they approach their daily work activities. De Certeau describes the city as a 'hero of political legend'. The concept city is the foundation for a kind of politics which presently may be losing its stronghold as we see the revolutions in Northern Africa, particularly through tactical behaviour that manifests as communication via the internet which has allowed people to organise themselves tactically outside of the states ability to police them. The question of bringing people to political awareness is a question of breaking patterns of routine and raising general awareness of place and Self. The user needs to find points of fixity geographically, but also psychologically to operate in the city. How is the meaning of the symbolic city of the individual user constructed as opposed to the symbolic city of the totalitarian system? The user, through walking, constructs narratives of meaning. De Certeau talks of Synecdoche; 'using a word in a sense which is part of another meaning of the same word'[8] and Asyndeton; 'suppression of linking words'[9] and the user is creative with his route taking short cuts and diversions, skipping sections, creating islands and leaving gaps that create 'myths'. The 'propr' names of city streets and places are appropriated by the user who attaches their own meaning. The resultant milieu is that of collective legend constructed from a collage of fragments of meaning and metaphor. 'Meaning creation' generates original content which can be represented and reflected upon. De Certeau writes 'What does travel ultimately produce if it is not, by a sort of reversal, an exploration of the deserted places of my memory?' What emerges is the importance of narrative, legends and stories in meaning creation and how meaning emerges in space from the debris of meaning in the complexity of the city. Through history, civilisations rise and fall. Human society has a vested interest in re-evaluating systems whether for the purposes of survival or progress. Extrapolating the theory of tactics and practices to the cosmological level; the big bang was initialised with a set of overriding conditions (a strategy) which set a process in motion. Matter in the universe self organises due to energy, gravity and other processes. According to classic thermodynamics, we live in a universe that is becoming ever more disordered.[10] However, this applies to equilibrium systems and non-equilibrium systems behave differently. In addition, living organisms self-organise and stockpile entropy through syntropy[11]. The panoptic prison alienated prisoners like the modern city tower blocks alienates labour as an instrument of modern capitalism[12]. When people interact there is certain type of creative energy. Perhaps, it is the organism's interest in interacting with others, and natural will to learn. If individuals are isolated from each other and from their environments then the possibility for unpredictable synergies to occur is removed which are 'key for emergence and evolution of life' [13]. The modern city evolved alongside industrial scientific and engineering systems which were less familiar with the possibilities of dynamic, turbulent systems and complex networks. In the Theory of the Deriv[14] Debord writes of social problems in a city space which are unaddressed by quantified methods of survey and which require an approach which collects qualitative anthropological measurements. The deriv is a 'drift' or wander which involves groups of up to two or three people who divert from their routine, habitual patterns of life to explore new geographical and mental realms. Participants monitor the environment and the affects of the environment on themselves, reflecting upon them and their reactions to them. The deriv facilitates self-reflection on the usually less than fully 'present' activity of the city street-walker to allow them to become more conscious of place and practices. The deriv requires conscious reflection and consideration of 'the other'. Some people would benefit from being prescribed a deriv in order to break the pattern of their usual everyday routine because the common system of working and movement is usually fixed to specific working times which involve being in the place of work. Ideally Debord saw that people would be on a continuous deriv which would have a profound effect on architecture in the city which would encourage diversions and exploration; for example walking over the city roofs.[15] A strict code of 'propr' behaviour in a city, as we have seen, prohibits a range of human activities from the public space which is the space where the majority of people spend their time. This raises the Freudian problematic of the suppression of certain desires, championing the super-ego and reinforcing inauthentic behaviour which restricts the possibility for collective learning by observing mutual behaviour. This could be also used as a method of manipulation and control. Perceptions are learnt from the environment (such as systems of control; schools, government, media) and then can be reinforced, for example, through the media. The problem to be addressed is that of how to create conditions for emergence from complex ecological networks in the face of repressive and in some ways redundant administrative order which categorises, alienates and prohibits. A possible solution is in raising awareness and consciousness of fixed patterns of movements in order to allow for the emergence of new meaning, and practices. The design project proposed a method via downloadable instructions to create a map which encourages deriv. To accompany this I created tool which allowed the creation of a similar map but via web based software built in Flash. The user searches their location on Google Maps and adds shapes and points before printing out a paper version to follow. With both methods I encourage the user to send their map with annotations, any photos or observations they made for analysis and possibly for representation as a souvenir. I did numerous test map walks with friends and the finished, drawn and annotated maps are an intriguing object in themselves which could be done repeatedly and then turned into a book. The bourgeois and class consciousness embedded in the propr and reflected in the modern capitalistic system is eroded when conditions are nurtured that facilitate collective consciousness and awareness.
 
[1] McDonnough, T., 2010. The Situationists and the City. Verso Books
[2] De Certeau, M., (1988., pg 29) The Practice of Everyday Life, University of California Press.
[3] De Certeau, M.,op cit. (pg 37)
[4] De Certeau, M., op. cit. (pg 92)
[5] Stier, M., The Transition from Feudalism to Capitalism. Website. Available at: < http://ih52.stier.net/notes/marx/feudalism.htm > [Accessed 2011].
[6] De Certeau, M.,op. cit. (pg 95)
[7] De Certeau, M.,op. cit. (pg 96)
[8] De Certeau, M., op. cit. (pg 101)
[9] De Certeau, M., op. cit. (pg 101)
[10] Rubi, M.J., 2008. the Long Arm of the Second Law. Scientific American (pg 62 63)
[11] Wikipedia, 2011. Negentropy. Website. Available at: < http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negentropy > [Accessed 2011].
[12] The Society of the Spectacle. 1973. Film. Guy Debord. France.
[13] Wikipedia, 2011. Emergence. Website. Available at < http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergence.> [Accessed 2011].
[14] McDonnough, T., ibid
[15] The Situationists New Babylon. Website. Available at < http://www.sauerthompson.com/junkforcode/archives/001058.html > [Accessed 2011].

item.title: The Tacit Knowledge of the Craftsman
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
"The object is an extension of, an expression of, the state: the rain expresses his longing, the berries his hunger, and the night his fear but nothing expresses his physical pain"[1] As pain is objectless, inexpressible through language. Imagining is its opposite. "It is impossible to imagine without imagining something."[2] For the craftsman the imagined object is the expression of the desire to realise it and in order to create the object he first needs to imagine it. Pain and imagining lie at opposite ends of the scale; at one end is the experienced intentional state and at the other is the imagined object. The attributes of consciousness and sentience are expressed on this scale through emotions and senses. Touch lies closer to pain she feels her fingers touching but on seeing a wheat field, she experiences the sheaves of wheat there rather than the self-conscious event of feeling in her eyes.[3] On sight, Scarry gives the example of a woman who becomes more aware of her eyes momentarily when bright light falls into them. If her eyesight fails over the years she becomes more aware of the act of seeing itself and it draws closer to pain. The craftsman, in the process of making is often required to use the full range of his senses and is therefore, through practice is exploring, structuring and developing his embodied consciousness. Should it happen that the world fails to provide an object, the imagination is there almost on an emergency stand-by basis, as a last resource for the generation of objects.[4] Though they may sometimes be inferior to naturally occurring objects, they will be superior to naturally occurring objectlessness.[5] A state of consciousness other than pain, such as hunger or desire, which is then deprived of its object, will begin to approach pain (as unsatisfied hunger or prolonged objectless longing). Pleasure comes from matching the imagined or desired object with an experienced state. The craftsman imagines objects and then ventures through a process to create them so the process of making should, in theory, be a satisfying and pleasurable one. iek in How to read Lacan states that often when there is something you desire it is best not to go directly for it but to effectively dance around it and be in proximity of it. This helps with the process of determining whether you really desire it or not and comprises the majority of the pleasure of fulfilling the desire. In a homologous way, the Freudian solution to the antinomy between the subject's approaching or running away from his objects of desire and the "constant speed" (and distance from him) of the object-cause of desire (objet petit a) resides in the curved space of desire: sometimes (as a rule, even), the shortest way to realize a desire is to by-pass its object-goal, to circulate around it, to postpone its encounter. What Lacan calls objet petit a is the agent of this curving: the unfathomable X on account of which, when we confront the object of our desire, more satisfaction is provided by dancing around it than by directly going at it. [6] Making something from a physical material reveals gradually an instantiated physical object to the imagined object. A craftsman has respect for this gradual, not wholly predictable process and understands its necessity for successfully realising the finished objective. A consumer on the other hand, who although works to earn money to afford the commodity, is not in contact with the making process of the things they buy. Once they have the means to afford the commodity they expect to (and usually get) it immediately once the decision is made to buy. The consumer still perceives on some level that the commodity appears as if by magic. The consumer does not learn, as does the craftsman, about the difference between the idea of the made object and the practice of making the object. Seeing as globalised culture is based on western consumer society, perhaps this goes some way to explain why the making of the world (Globalisation) is being informed in this consumerist way. It depends whether the power to make the world is with those who think like craftsmen or those who think like consumers. I think the latter is more predominantly the case. This leads me to question which kind of knowledge, epistemological or tacit, is most valued in society, which goes beyond the scope of this essay. I visited a furniture maker and bicycle frame builders workshop, a bicycle repair workshop and a designer-maker studio. The furniture maker was able to build a workshop on his parents land, the frame builder after avoiding rent by squatting for a number of years had a second job in order to afford to rent his workshop and the repair workshop and studio were part of a socially-funded project. The imagined objects of desire, whether furniture, bikes, designed objects or social change, provide a motivation to do something to provide the state to satisfy them (e.g. work) which allows for the bringing together of the necessary resources and space to be able to focus their work onto the desired objects. Those who have the capability to obtain or already have available resources can realise their desires whilst those who dont have to make do or work for someone else who already has capital. The digital realm provides a cheaply accessible vent for the urge to imagine and make. Download a pixelated image of a desired object, write a blog post, or communicate about the object via social networking. Before digital media it could be argued that there was more necessity to use the space of the imagination (and physical materials) to make things up whereas the digital space re-presents many already formed objects and ideas (that have been archived during the lifespan of the internet) as data on hard disks in air-conditioned server rooms, which to an extent, bypasses the appreciation for the materiality of making. The imagination is temporal and linked to emotions. Ideas rise into consciousness and then fade away. As time passes some ideas may endure where others will not. However, with digital memory all ideas recorded have to be chosen to be forgotten through deletion or are lost by accident through equipment failure or human error. It has brought into being the demand for idea (as if they were synonymous with thoughts and files on disk) management. Ideas are treated as individual, enduring entities rather than ephemeral gestures existing in a network of associations. The digital space seems to make the imagination itself a manipulatable object. Ideas go through a complex process before they re-emerge in consciousness. They are forgotten or part forgotten, discarded or fragmented and are absorbed into areas of the long-term memory and unconscious. They are not solid, whole or able to be fully rationalised as such. In addition if an idea is focussed on, then being fully present to accept new input is forfeited. Knowledge on the Internet (or other representational medium) is different to that gained through the process of experiential making which results in tacit knowledge[7]. Perhaps this aspect of technological development of privileging epistemological knowledge can also be attributed to for increasingly homogenised globalised culture. In the workshops that I visited there was an unavoidable connection with practice, materials, machines and other people. An idea that is intended to be revealed in a material can be shared and the what and how to make decided through communication and consensus around the things existing out there in the world. There is an innate awareness and understanding of the interconnectedness of things, interdependence and intersubjectivity. However this is not to say that the making process that I observed was always a collaborative one. The making process could be very solitary. The furniture maker got into-the-zone, a state of flow, absorbed in the process and was seemingly unaware of anything outside of the object of focussed attention. There is an inherent danger in becoming lost in this state when there is the need to break the flow and return to the idea to direct the process which is something that the skilled craftsmen learns to do. When I watched the craftsmen at work it was clear that the process was a considered (and slow) one whether taking time to accurately configure a jig in which to hold tubes which would be welded into a bike frame or gradually and carefully removing small pieces of wood with a chisel to get the pieces of a dovetail joint to the point where they can be tapped evenly together with a wooden mallet. The process required a great deal of patience. To the non-expert onlooker this slow process could become frustrating to watch. I was aware of how much time and effort was being poured into the process. At least part of the aim (and the common perception of others for why the work was being done) was that the work would translate to monetary value in the sale of the object. It would be interesting to do a more in depth study of the personal reasons of the craftsmen. With each mark or adjustment made, the craftsmen I observed took great care. Unlike on a computer, there is no undo button. If a mistake is made it is clear to see that further practice and closer observation is required. Ordinary perception is self-modifying because at the very heart, it alters and nullifies its own content, continually exchange one for another, exercising control over the direction and content of touch, hearing, seeing, smell and taste[8] The craftsman has to work hard to obtain a higher level of observation to close the gap between subjective perception and objective reality in order to be able to accurately make things real in the world. The frame builder who produces a frame that breaks cannot avoid the fact that their welds were poorly executed. It cannot be selected out of perception (because they will be held to account by the cyclist). For Scarry, culture is the canon of imagined objects collectively recognised as nearest to the perfect fit for different desires. The closer that a work gets to the perfect fit the more it is perceived as art and accepted into culture, whereas the more it is unable to bring forth an object or is cut off from it, the closer it is to pain. Within the trade there is a culture of imagined standards amongst tradesmen displayed in the universally recognisable quality of the craftsmanship which differs from the relationship that consumers have between each other with regards to objects which tends to be based on envy and desiring what the other has. However, the notion of Open Product[9] may stimulate the possibility for the consumer to enter the realm of the craftsman and therefore encourage appreciation for craftsmanship through experience. In a job creating corporate websites, considerable time, effort and technical know-how was required in production, but the result was physically objectless. I was only able to imagine that some unknown people had visited the website. There was no mark of my own on the product, no feedback given and a colleague could delete it from existence with a press of a button. On the contrary, the furniture maker produces objects, which constitute works that are attributed to them. Although, the final object is cut off from the maker at least they have the pleasure of handing it to their customer and knowing that it exists somewhere. However, a website could facilitate a behaviour which is not connected to place like the piece of furniture is. When a website becomes a centre-point for a shared idea, is open to continuous interpretation and narrative creation then the possibilities for new additional realities are opened up, similar to Open Product. The craftsman has an unavoidable relationship to his tools. The workshops I visited were spaces to store tools but there is more to the workshop as a space than is commonly perceived which could make an interesting future project. Most obviously, in the workshop, could be found all manner of tools that were specific to the needs of the maker. What is the relation between the maker and the tools? Scarry writes of a chisel, which allows for a small movement of the hand to be focussed into the small surface area of the sharp edge. The saw allows the arm to effectively become extended and sharp and cut into wood. The pressure of the arm moving back and forth is magnified into a huge power of altering[10]. With this tool there is a clear usage, which directly achieves its purpose. The furniture maker with his woodworking tools is in direct relationship with this effect through his tools. The multiplying effect is clearly experienced (although perhaps taken for granted over time). The tool as an extension of the makers body disappears in the process of its use. It is ready-at-hand. Paul Dourish gives the example of the computer mouse. You feel as though you are operating the menus, icons and so on directly, and not as though youre asking the mouse to do it on your behalf. [11] The maker is usually only aware of the tool when it breaks and then it becomes a tool that requires repairing or is discarded as useless. Because the tool is still perceived as a tool, it never becomes what Heidegger described as present-at-hand. It would become present-at-hand if the tool became an object of enquiry as an entity in itself. Shaviro in his essay of the same name[12] mentions the short story The Universe of Things by Gwyneth Jones. The story elaborates that tools are not what they seem. A mechanic is asked to fix a human-car, which is used by an alien (called an Aleutian). The alien has tools that are alive and move about and the mechanic feels in awe of them.
