The mechanic wants to impress the alien so instead of using his normal machine tools, he decides to use his most basic manual tools. He does this as a last ditch attempt to, beholding the advanced technology of the tools of the alien, maintain personal worth through a mystique of craftsmanship. However, his endeavour falls through when his tools also come alive and seem to have a life of their own aside from their use. They are imbued with living slime... full of self, of human substance, but appear as other. The mechanic holds a system of reference for how the tools should be used of which he is very knowledgeable. However, he does not see beyond this that they possess a further depth and have their own innate tendencies. Humans only ally with their tools and they cannot do anything without their tools. The craftsman is perhaps more aware (if only subconsciously) of the intrinsic weakness of humans and their reliance on tools, materials and other alliances. Humans arise from this as (merely?) good organisers, perhaps even stewards of these objects and therefore are bound with a responsibility to them. This evokes Heideggers notion of humans becoming in a positive sense as having this kind of relationship to the world. Artefacts affect the world because they become part of the visual field of anyone else[13] which affects the person through emotion and perception. Unlike a weapon, which acts directly on the body, it alters the world without hurting. A person using a weapon or a tool can therefore take credit for experiencing a large alteration without himself experiencing any direct bodily alteration. He experiences alteration without himself risking the aversiveness that ordinarily accompanies self-alteration, he objectifies his presence in the world through the alterability of his world[14] Scarrys work is also about violence in the sense of directly altering bodies, but also violence in the sense of the will to dominate others. The craftsman usually uses their ability to change the world in a constructive way but the craftsman in his workshop is surrounded by tools, which could be repurposed as weapons. Structuring and making the world can be used to dominate or set free. It is in the interests of the 'structures of domination to monitor and control those who make and make the capability to make. Does this not go some way to explain why so much high tech research and development starts out in the military and new technology with this potential is often assimilated or revealed to have emerged there? In the film, 2001:A Space Odyssey the bone is used as a tool to dominate other chimps, and could be thought of as the first military act of violence as well as the first example of tool use. In recent years the military, in terms of the weapons it has available to it is often rebranded as a peacekeeping force that uses their tools for constructive purposes but the weapons (and material and making resources) that the military have, even if they are not used or used for constructive purposes, are still perceived as a threat. ieks notion of the virtual invokes that authoritys threat must remain virtual to be the greatest perceived threat. Does this not also work in the context of humans inability to act on a significant problem such as ecological catastrophe? The threat appears virtual because it is not locally experienced as itself and therefore appears virtual. Structures of domination and control, through their remaining virtual, reinforce a wide inability to act on anything that does not appear a direct threat and reinforces the general will to dominate others as the western, capitalist raison dtre e.g. competition (use of humans as tools e.g. human resources or humans as standing reserve). What was previously perceived as Nature, according to Timothy Morton, is actually a meshwork of objects and global warming an example of a hyperobject[15] because it is non-local and reveals itself through a history of traces. It challenges the traditional anthropological way of conceiving problem solving because it is, as one of the attributes of Mortons theory (and others in the Object Oriented Ontology area of thought) a reversal of the traditional anthropocentric way of perceiving objects. This is one example of the problem of the subject-object privileging basis of ontological thought that OOO aims to address[16]. It is also a critique of the systems-emphasis of the modern era. Consequentially, it implies the need for a general retooling and critique of systems, in order to deal with a future with an awareness of these hyperobjects (and general shift towards present-at-hand type object awareness). The intertwined problems of domination and ecological catastrophe require Heideggers Destruktion for the same reasons that it is necessary to re-evaluate traditional systems that are failing to deal with urgent problems in the present, particularly those which have become so familiar that they have fallen from awareness. In terms of Heideggers ready-to-hand and present-at-hand; when the tools are broken, then a path forward could be to do a study on the tool itself in order to discover the origins of its need and display how that need may differ from the present need. For example, the tools, which at present are being used but failing to deal with ecological catastrophe or revolution. However, some occurrences like when sea water engulfs the Carteret islands and the people have to evacuate to higher ground[17] or when a policemans fist strikes a protesters face[18] there is a need to respond directly in the moment and learn from the experience, in the words of iek: This requires good science, not philosophy.[19]
[1] Scarry, E. (1965, pg 165-166) The Body in Pain, Oxford University Press.
[2] Scarry, E. The Body in Pain, op cit.
[3] Scarry, E. The Body in Pain, op cit.
[4] Scarry, E. The Body in Pain, op cit.
[5] Scarry, E. The Body in Pain, op cit.
[6]iek, S. How to Read Lacan. [online]. Available at: < http://www.lacan.com/zizalien.htm > [Accessed 2011].
[7] Tsoukas, H. (2004, pg 141-149) Complex Knowledge, OUP Oxford.
[8] Scarry, E. (1965, pg 168) op cit.
[9] Magus, M. PhD research. Open Product. [online]. Available at: http://openproduct.blogspot.com/. [Accessed 29 November 2011].
[10] Scarry, E. (1965, pg 175) op cit.
[11] Dourish, P. (2004, pg. 109) Where the Action is, MIT Press.
[12] Shaviro, S. (2011) The Universe of Things. [online]. Available at < http://www.shaviro.com/Othertexts/Things.pdf > [Accessed 11 November 2011]
[13] Scarry, E. (1965, pg 178) ibid.
[14] Scarry, E. (1965, pg 178) ibid.  
[15] Morton, T. The Dawn of the Hyperobjects. [online video]. Available at: <http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NS8b87jnqnw>. [Accessed 11 November 2011].
[16] Graham Harman on the history of OOO. [online video]. Available at: < http://www.ustream.tv/recorded/11193628>. [Accessed 29 November 2011].
[17] Journey to the Sinking Islands. [online]. Available at: < http://journeytothesinkinglands.wordpress.com/> [Accessed 28 November 2011].
[18] Watch: police punch students at demo. [online]. Available at: < http://liberalconspiracy.org/2010/12/01/watch-policeman-punches-student-at-protests/> [Accessed 28 November 2011].
[19] iek, 2005 [documentary] Directed by Astral Taylor. USA: Zeitgeist Films.

item.title: The Technology of Sense
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Download PDF Technology Essay >>

item.title: The Technology of Sense Part II
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Catherine Malabou in 'What Should We Do with Our Brain?' illustrates how current understanding of neuroscience and the brain is appropriated by different areas of society. Her work focuses on the recent form of capitalism. Previous understanding of the brain was that it was a kind of computer which had a top-down, command/control, cause-effect relationship between thought and action. New understanding shows that the brain is not like this but an immense network of synaptic connections from which structures emerge. In addition, the brain is adaptable to new ideas around a pivotal genetic blue print. This constitutes its plasticity and implies an inbuilt propensity to be better at certain things rather than endless flexibility to do new things. It implies that emergent potential should be nurtured as opposed to people being to put to use for whatever is in economic demand at the time. It advocates a strengthening of being critical about what one is willing to do and nurturing one's own 'revealing' and 'becoming'. Heidegger's concept of 'Gestell' in German usually means skeleton or book-rack. However, he uses it in an abstract sense to describe how the world is framed in a certain way of understanding, whether through our own personal framing of reality, or that constituted by technology. Nancy similarly states, 'we touch our limits on all sides, our gaze touches its limits on all sides'. We are confined by our own directional ability, our binding to physical movement, our position of interrelationality, and in Cartesian built space. What governs modern technology is this will to categorise and frame world(s) in a certain way. The model of causality that shapes modern physics is that of numbers and calculations and views the world as calculable and orderable into a system of information, to which Heidegger holds this way of viewing the world as accountable. How do we save ourselves from this situation? Heidegger believes we are already caught up in an enframing which structures our reality but we can gain a perspective on our own orientation to the world and therefore get a perspective on technology. Humanity's primal relationship to the world is still maintained because it is still experiencing the natural world revealing itself, as it always does, as a bursting forth. Any technology developed should not further blind humans from nature revealing itself to us in this primal way. It should encourage affective, embodied 'being there' in the world and an observance of how the real is revealed to us. Our own orientation to the world is the essence of technology. Heidegger proposes two possible futures: one is a techno-dystopia ruled by human hubris and anthropocentric narcissism where we miss the truth of the world because of our obsession with ordering and controlling it; and the other is where we accept that humanity is on its way to arriving to a more profound way of being and establishing a non-destructive relationship with nature. For Nancy the question of the confines of space is the question of technology stating that if there is a philosophy of nature today it would be a philosophy of confines. He cites the film, '2001: A Space Odyssey', in which man thinks he is going to space to 'secure himself an empire' but instead finds the limits of himself. Furthermore, 'to touch it is to pass it'. Once we reach the boundaries we know them and we can expand them but we can never have a deterministic objective reality with absolute knowledge. The quest to find the limit has been driven partly by the religious concept of something beyond, but as we find that we are constrained by the logic of the limit, we can instead focus on the world here, rather than questing for something beyond. Heidegger looks deeper into the definition of essence. In traditional philosophy it means 'what' but according to Plato and Aristotle, it meant something which 'remains permanently' or endures. Heidegger rewords this using 'granting' which is the way that the world is granted and gives itself to us. With this comes the huge responsibility of not only looking after it in an environmental sense but also caring for every-thing including 'Being'. Heidegger concludes his essay by referring again to the ancient Greeks who knew art not as a spectacle or consumable culture, but rather as something which brought together all aspects of society, including politics and religion into a unifying entity. Art was a driving force which unified humans into a creative existence, concerned not with exploiting, manipulating, measuring and turning things to standing reserve but with 'coming to being'. This unification could be a 'collective sense' that transcends the need to find meaning, because meaning would be embodied in the act of artistic existence and follow the conditions of the aforementioned 'revealing'. It is important that community and sovereignty are not forced upon the citizens or reduce the citizens to the material of the community creating a 'with us' or 'against us'. Nancy states that that 'The Enlightenment' of the eighteenth century brought sense to the world but then fell foul of an over-riding approach of reason and scepticism which cancelled each other out. Nancy proposes rearranging them so that, instead, they multiply each other by creating 'other gatherings of sense'[39], established through praxis which can be related to Heidegger's tekne and creative society. There is a need for empowerment and motivational energy to bring this 'artistic existence' into being through a more playful approach to being; approaching it from many different perspectives and making experimentations, as Derrida did with language. Heidegger quotes the poet Hlderlin 'where the danger is, the saving power grows also'[40]. Is it possible that the destructive path of modern technology we have today has been necessary in order that out of it can rise a new awareness? When Nancy speaks of love he notions of the energy, 'k(nots) of sense'[41], glue which drives this new form of society. 'Love begins in pure truth (punctuality, myth) and must, in order to last come to make sense'[42]. It is also a question of common space, the political, which starts in sense, and is punctuated by truth. 'Totalitarianism' is sense, presented as truth, or in other words, an ideology. Humans historically tend to eventually overcome totalitarianism with a drive for something better, or the regime implodes because of this dislocation of sense. The sense in Heidegger's society would be constituted by the aforementioned processes of revealing, making sense without ideology. Political space is there for the making. We live in a time of revolution which we can easily see by turning our attention to North Africa. The internet is at its essence a way for communication across bureaucratic boundaries and structures of society and law but it is by no means an absolute solution and is riddled with issues. Perhaps in this space we find a model for this process of 'revealing' and 'becoming'. More importantly is the question of how action in the internet space crosses over into the physical space and what is lost in translation. The internet provides a model for new arrangements of sense but is problematic due its potential to distance and its material nature. We have to be careful about using the internet as a model for change especially with ideas of some kind of democracy emerging from it. 'I do not at all believe in what I call automatic democracy. I believe in reflection, not reflex. '[43] Everyone needs to become to some degree, a technician, philosopher and a critic and engage politically. 'Play at being a critic. Deconstruct the game in order to play with it. Instead of accepting the rules, challenge and modify them. Without the freedom to critique and reconstruct, there is no truly free game: we are addicts and nothing more. '[44] Well designed education is needed to facilitate a critical perspective and an understanding of the significance of the political space of the city should be highly valued. Designers have a particular responsibility as those who deliberately bring worlds into being. The situation with technology is a political responsibility because it concerns how people are able to have the capability to gain a sense of perspective on technology. In the face of the 'end of history' in the aforementioned ways, particularly cultural, it is time for people to look to their own personal experience and process and to cultivate a motivational energy (possibly aided by a mindfulness of finitude and the limitations of human understanding and ability). 'at every instant, here and now while I write and while you read, it could be absolutely necessary and pressing to abandon these thoughts and give oneself up in haste to the event'[45].

item.title: Logo Design Process
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A logo is a graphical element (ideogram, symbol, emblem, icon, sign) that, together with its logotype (a uniquely set and arranged typeface) form a trademark or commercial brand. Typically, a logo's design is for immediate recognition. The logo is one aspect of a company's commercial brand, economic or academic entity, and its shapes, colors, fonts, and images usually are different from others in a similar market. Logos are also used to identify organizations and other non-commercial entities.1 A logo reflects a businesss commercial brand through the use of shape, fonts, colour, and / or images. A logo aims to inspire trust, recognition and admiration for a company or product. Logo design process:
  1. The Design Brief
  2. Research and Brainstorming-Client competition, trends in the market, what sets the client apart, the history of the business, the future, the current brand, and the one aspired towards.
  3. Sketching-Sketching ideas helps me to generate a large number of possible directions. Most of them will eventually be made redundant, but the point is to think laterally and not rule anything out in order to achieve the most effective logo design. I frequently mention sketching in blog posts and portfolio entries, and its a method also used by other design disciplinesweb design, architecture etc.
  4. Prototyping and Conceptualising (See Step 5)
  5. Send to Client for Review - leave colour out until afterwards
  6. Revise and Add Finishing Touches
  7. Supply Files to Client and Provide Customer Service
Information to collect:
  • Name of the service/product:
  • Any slogans to use?
  • Any specific color schemes in mind?
  • What are you trying to convey through the logo?
Thumbnail sketches Design in illustrator / Photoshop
  • Experiment with the font which might work well for the logoe.g taxi business classic, businesslike, sans-serif, sporty, slick
  • Think of what exactly the product/service/site is all about
  • Google image search on taxis
Evolution of the design
  • SIMPLIFY. SIMPLIFY. SIMPLIFY. KISS method, (keep it simple, stupid)
  • Stay away fromgradients, bevels, and dropshadows
  • Your logo is not your brand; it is -representing- your brand. McDonalds for example, does not have a the cheapest, fastest Hamburger in their logo - but everyone knows what the arched "M" means.
Aspect Ratios.
  • The aspect ratio (the relationship between the height and width of a logo) is critical.
  • A logo that is too tall and skinny, or too wide and short, is not visually pleasing, and you'll end up with all sorts of layout issues when it comes to setting up your logo in artwork, especially when combined with other graphic elements (ie: business card, websites, etc).
  • A logo that is closer to a 'golden mean' (almost the aspect relationship of a business card) is much more pleasing and more adaptable to working in other artwork.
  • Square & circle logos are very strong visually due to their 'square aspect ratio' (see her for more on logo aspect ratios & logo footprints).
  • Strive to be 'different'.
  • Color is a secondary factor in your logo.
  • The most important part of your logo project is the design itself.
  • Present to the client and make relevant changes
Endnotes 1. Wikipedia entry on Logo - Available athttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logo - Accessed 2011 Featured image from:http://360imaginativedesigns.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/pm_logo_sketches.jpg

What is a logo?

A logo is a graphical element (ideogram, symbol, emblem, icon, sign) that, together with its logotype (a uniquely set and arranged typeface) form a trademark or commercial brand. Typically, a logo's design is for immediate recognition.[1] The logo is one aspect of a company's commercial brand, or economic or academic entity, and its shapes, colors, fonts, and images usually are different from others in a similar market. Logos are also used to identify organizations and other non-commercial entities. (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logo)

A logo is not just a mark it reflects a businesss commercial brand through the use of shape, fonts, colour, and / or images. A logo is for inspiring trust, recognition and admiration for a company or product and it is our job as designers to create an identity that will do its job.

Logo design process:

  1. The Design Brief

  2. Research and Brainstorming-Client competition, trends in the market, what sets the client apart, the history of the business, the future, the current brand, and the one aspired towards.

  3. Sketching-Sketching ideas helps me to generate a large number of possible directions. Most of them will eventually be made redundant, but the point is to think laterally and not rule anything out in order to achieve the most effective logo design. I frequently mention sketching in blog posts and portfolio entries, and its a method also used by other design disciplinesweb design, architecture etc.

  4. Prototyping and Conceptualising (See Step 5)

  5. Send to Client for Review - leave colour out until afterwards

  6. Revise and Add Finishing Touches

  7. Supply Files to Client and Provide Customer Service

Information to collect:

Name of the service/product:

Any slogans to use?

Any specific color schemes in mind?

What are you trying to convey through the logo?

Any other specifics....

Thumbnail sketches

Design in illustrator / photoshop

  1. Experiment with the font which might work well for the logo

  2. e.g taxi business= classic, businesslike, probably sans-serif, sporty, slick

  3. think of what exactly the product/service/site is all about

  4. google image search on taxis

Evolution of the design

  1. SIMPLIFY. SIMPLIFY. SIMPLIFY. I can't stress this enough. We all know the KISS method, (keep it simple, stupid) - but many times designers (and myself) forget to apply it to logo design.

  2. Other things I see are gradients, bevels, and dropshadows. These don't transition well in enlargement and printing - stay away from these.

  3. Your logo will NOT tell your story. Your logo is NOT YOUR BRAND. When you create a logo for a company (whether that be for yourself or for another client), remember that your logo is not your brand; it is -representing- your brand. McDonalds for example, does not have a the cheapest, fastest Hamburger in their logo - but everyone knows what the arched "M" means.

  4. Aspect Ratios.

  5. The aspect ratio (the relationship between the height and width of a logo) is critical. A logo that is too tall and skinny, or too wide and short, is not visually pleasing, and you'll end up with all sorts of layout issues when it comes to setting up your logo in artwork, especially when combined with other graphic elements (ie: business card, websites, etc). A logo that is closer to a 'golden mean' (almost the aspect relationship of a business card) is much more pleasing and more adaptable to working in other artwork. Square is pretty cool too - circle logos are very strong visually due to their 'square aspect ratio' (see her for more on logo aspect ratios & logo footprints).

  6. Strive to be 'different'.

  7. You'd be surprised how many clients have asked that we design logos that are very similar to their competitors. Kinds misses the point, no? The idea of your own logo is just that - your own logo.

  8. Color is a secondary factor in your logo.

  9. The most important part of your logo project is the design itself. Oh sure, it's nice to see your logo in the colors that you will eventually use, but in the initial stages of any design process the colors are of secondary importance. They can always be changed,or edited later. Now, having said that...

Present to the client and make relevant changes

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Appreciating the commitment you put into your blog and detailed information you offer. It's nice to come across a blog every once in a while that isn't the same old rehashed information. Fantastic read! I've saved your site and I'm adding your RSS feeds to my Google account.

item.title: Minimal Zen Things Done
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In order to organise your thoughts and your time try the following approach adapted from Zen Habits.
  1. Capture. Get a notebook and carry it everywhere. Write down all your thoughts, ideas, to-do items, doodles, whatever. Download a to-do list program like Abstract Spoon To-do list and regularly transfer the items into this list. Have a physical inbox in your workplace or home- and put incoming stuff in it.
  2. Process. Go through your to-do list and inbox and process the items quickly, making quick decisions. Do it at least once a day. If it takes less that two minutes to do the task or deal with the item, do it, otherwise either delegate it, or give it a date or put it back on your to-do list or file it away in an archive. Give it a status: action, waiting, someday maybe, etc. Check out these GTD desktop wallpapers.
  3. Plan. Time plans are massively important. Each week set your big rocks- max 3 per week, the big things you want to achieve. Each day set max three MITs (most important tasks) make sure you finish them by the end of the day but be realistic. Do your MITs early in the day if possible and get them out of the way. You can try an open-source project management program like Open Workbench. If you work in an organisation, particularly charity with a small budget you could try a collaborative application like Collabtive or Open Atrium
  4. Do. Focus on one task at a time, and eliminate distractions. Write any incoming requests or distractions in your capture notebook as per step one.
Featured image from:http://www.foto8.com/issue06/zen/zen07.jpg

item.title: Six Thinking Hats
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Six thinking hats are six imaginary hats that you put on in order to consider a problem or situation from a variety of different angles in order to get a range of perspectives as opposed to using the predominant western logic of (black) logic negative thinking (also functionalist, productivist, rational, controlling, deterministic).
  • white - facts
  • red - emotions
  • yellow - logic positive
  • black - logic negative
  • green - creative generative
  • blue - thinking about thinking
The book Six Thinking Hats can be bought here.

item.title: Thinking Things
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A group of people sit at a table. A large sheet of paper is laid out on the table. On it is drawn three large circles and the whole thing is split into 6 segments. Each segment represents an aspect of the lifestyle of a product. The product is placed in the centre of the circle. Segments included (not limited to):Extraction, production, retail, disposal, transportation In the workshop with Pi studio we used 'lensing' to frame the object in the context of a photo which related to the segment on the paper. For example:
  • the extraction lens had a picture of a mining machine at a mill
  • the manufacturer lens had a photograph of a row of Chinese factory workers
There were numerous lenses for the same segment but with different photos. When the participant looks through the lens they talk about their observations and notes are made in the segment space on the circle in order to generate a more holistic understanding of the object. There were often many 'grey areas' - things which it was not possible to know - 'known unknowns'. For example, we don't know the psychological effect of the factory work on the Chinese workers or we don't know the material composition of the object just by looking at it. This book Closed-Loop Supply Chains: New Developments to Improve the Sustainability of Business Practices (Supply Chain Integration Modeling, Optimization and Application) touches on some of the issues that exist in manufacturing practices and how to make them more sustainable. These books may also be of use when thinking 'things': The Order of Things: Archaeology of the Human Sciences (Routledge Classics) The Shape of Things: A Philosophy of Design Alien Phenomenology, or What it's Like to be a Thing (Posthumanities)

item.title: Linguistic Playfulness
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is something which can be done either alone or in a group. It can be done as an ideation tool but also potentially to create a final product. There are quite a few different options for this: 1. Automatic writing. Write the first thing that comes into your head and keep writing not analysing or evaluating what you write. Notice the mental layers which try to take over and rationalise the flow. 2. Write a short narrative. For example, of an event, like an accident or a particular noteworthy occurence. Then rewrite it from different viewpoints. E.g. from the dog's perspective, 1st person, 2nd person, 3rd person, as a spectator, as the protagonist, as the news reporter afterwards, as a gossiping teenager. 3. Replace words and characters. Metaphor and metanomy (substitute an associative part for a whole).Literary forms tend to gravitate between the poles.Look at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georges_Perec Oulipo (French pronunciation: [ulipo], short for French: Ouvroir de littrature potentielle; roughly translated: "workshop of potential literature") is a loose gathering of (mainly) French-speaking writers and mathematicians which seeks to create works using constrained writing techniques. It was founded in 1960 by Raymond Queneau and Franois Le Lionnais. Other notable members include novelists Georges Perec and Italo Calvino, poet Oskar Pastior and poet/mathematician Jacques Roubaud. Constrained writing Aliterary technique in which the writer is bound by some condition that forbids certain things or imposes a pattern.Constraints are very common in poetry, which often requires the writer to use a particular verse form. In the literary sense, which is motivated by more aesthetic concerns. For example:
  • Lipogram: a letter (commonly e or o) is outlawed.
  • Palindromes, such as the word radar, read the same forwards and backwards.
  • Alliteratives, in which every word must start with the same letter (or subset of letters; see Alphabetical Africa).
  • Acrostics: first letter of each word/sentence/paragraph forms a word or sentence.
  • Reverse-lipograms: each word must contain a particular letter.
  • Anglish, favouring Anglo-Saxon words over Greek and Roman words.
  • Anagrams, words or sentences formed by rearranging the letters of another.
  • Aleatory, where the reader supplies a random input.
  • Chaterism Where the length of words in a phrase or sentence increase or decrease in a uniform, mathematical way as in "I am the best Greek bowler running", or "hindering whatever tactics appear".
  • Univocalic poetry, using only one vowel.
  • Bilingual homophonous poetry, where the poem makes sense in two different languages at the same time, thus constituting two simultaneous homophonous poems.[1]
  • Limitations in punctuation, such as Peter Carey's book True History of the Kelly Gang, which features no commas.
  • Mandated vocabulary, where the writer must include specific words, chosen a priori, along with the writer's own freely chosen words (for example, Quadrivial Quandary, a website that solicits individual sentences containing all four words in a daily selection).
  • E-Prime, where all forms of the verb "to be" are disallowed, for clarity.
Death of the author The author is no longer seen as a special chap who creates wonderous material which the readers then passively consume. Readers, read into, and appropriate content.The story is written with the objective that the reader appropriates the text. Structuralism asks us to reconsider the image of the individual and the strength of the individual's power. Umberto Eco - the structure of language is equal to the structure of society. Idealogy interpellates or hails us and we respond to it's signs in a reflex-like fashion.What does not fit in the sign system is discarded. Derrida / Foucault critique of structuralism because it classifies and categorises. Derrida's binary opposites e.g. Man-woman - loaded binary opposite. Cover image by:http://www.flickr.com/photos/kmasback/485287509/

item.title: A Brief Explosion
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
You receive a brief or have an idea which you think is worthwhile taking forward.Here are some methods to unpick and harness the details and scope of the brief. Take the brief, read it, and highlight the bits which you find interesting or noteworthy then you could do the following: Explore why the brief exists
  • How is the brief is situated in a network of meaning.
For example, look at its context
A chair sits in a room placed under a table. This is normal but it wouldn't be if the chair was attached to the ceiling or in the washing machine for example.
  Fragment
  • Cut the brief up into pieces and rearrange the pieces.
Pictoralise
  • Make drawings and sketches to visualise the brief.
  • A storyboard or would be a way to visualise / pictoralise the brief.
  • Storyboards are graphic organizers such as a series of illustrations or images displayed in sequence for the purpose of pre-visualizing a motion picture, animation, motion graphic or interactive media sequence, including website interactivity.
  • Link to website with good information about storyboards.
Analyse
  • What are the categories of language:quotes, instructions, anecdotes.
Reassemble
  • Reconnect the pieces in different ways.
  • You could use the technique of mind-mapping tofind connections between objects, words, images, concepts.
  • Intermingle these with written nodes of meaning and notes.
  • There may be significant quotes within the brief which can be made more prominent
  • Search around the subject matter for significant quotes or maxims
  • Look at the most prominent philosophers/ thinkers around the subject area and include some quotes from them.
Develop
  • Elaborate on the elements of the brief which are most interesting / noteworthy - perhaps with a mind map.
Reduce
  • To the interactions of their parts
  • To simpler or more fundamental things.
  • To a philosophical position - e.g. a complex system is nothing but the sum of its parts, and that an account of it can be reduced to accounts of individual constituents.
Narrattavise
  • Give it meaning by constructing a narrative / story
  • Look for narratives which arise within the brief which may or may not have deliberately been put there (if the brief was assigned to you) or look for narratives which you have perhaps unconsciously given over to it.
Processuralise
  • Turn the brief from it's existing format into a process.
  • Is there a process implied in the brief?
  • Is there one which would suite the brief better than another?
Linguistic breakdown
  • Look into the etymology of keywords.
   
Endnotes
Note:you might want to meditate on this 1. Wikipedia entry on Reductionism - Available at -http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reductionism - Accessed 2011 2. Wikipedia entry onDeconstructivism- Available at -http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deconstructivism- Accessed 2011 3. Wikipedia entry onStoryboarding- Available at -http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Storyboarding- Accessed 2011

item.title: Lefebvre's Research Method
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Descriptive (primary research): Observation
  • Observe practices through photography, film, sketching. For example what constitutes an open product, a game, 'the proper', a tent, a lifestyle, a house, a dwelling, a bicycle, a tool, a container?
Analytico-historic (secondary research)
  • Look at the the history of the object / subject / place / concept / process in the brief through archives, books, internet.
Historico-progressive
  • Look at the social, economic, political context / implication of the object / subject / place / concept / process and consider the future.
Following Eldens interpretation, let me try to concretize the triad model within an organisational scenario. On the one hand, we have an abstract space of pure mathematical figures and verbal messages manifested in the design of offices, organisational rules and symbols, and so on (Spicer and Taylor, 2004). On the other, an all-too-material, and therefore indifferent space, consisting of the flows of labour, money, information (Harvey, 1990) and every physical movement of employees: their opening doors, sipping coffee, and etc. In between of these two poles, there is the lived space, a space of pure subjectivity, of human experiences (Watkins, 2005), of peoples sense-making, imagination, and feeling that is, their local knowledge of the organisational space as they encounter it. In so far that our experiences always take place in pre-fabricated physical spaces, and that what we think may not coincide with what we do, the lived space embodies both conceived and perceived spaces without being reducible to either. 2.). The important thing to notice here is that Lefebvre has always associated the diversity of space which he later develops into his triad model with the changing of perspectives of onlookers. "Anything that we are aware of at a given moment forms part of our consciousness, making conscious experience at once the most familiar and most mysterious aspect of our lives." Schneider and Velmans, 2007[4] www.ephemeraweb.org Lefebvre's seminal work The Production of Space is available here. What Is Lived Space? - Zhongyuan Zhang S. Elden (2004) Understanding Lefebvre: Theory and the Possible. London: Continuum. (PB, pp. 288,

item.title: Observation Research Design
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Considering the Levebvre model of research take the descriptive observation primary research part and take that as the exercise. Structure all the ways in which it is possible to observe:
  • Photography
  • Filming
  • Looking
  • Drawing
  • others...
And consider the tools available: Different scales of looking - microscope, magnifying glass, binoculars, tele-presence (e.g. webcam surveillance camera). Use methods which are compatible with with what you are observing or deliberately don't! Featured image from:http://www.clker.com/cliparts/8/b/a/2/12074319631273723948scenic%20vewpoint%20view%20point%20black.svg.hi.png

item.title: Hanging out with the 'I' thought
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is a section from my first book from my Ride Earth bicycle travels: We arrive in Budapest and stay with a curious fellow who lives in a Yurt called David. David was deliberately very open with his own philosophy on life. At night he created a social situation which incubated discussion. We sat around the camp-fire, drank red wine from tall glasses and discussed philosophy. David's spoke of the 'Person Centred Theory' of Carl Rogers which states that people are essentially good and healthy which differs greatly from the psychoanalytic focus on abnormal behaviour epitomised by Freud. The theory is concerned with development of the Self. How this is developed through interacting with others and how people acquire 'conditions of worth'. People have experienced 'positive regard' from others such as their parents, and develop conditions of worth based on these experiences. The need to continue to feel this 'positive regard' leads the individual to be selective in their perception of the world. This leads to an "incongruence" between the perceived Self and the actual experience of the organism, resulting in possible confusion, tension, and maladaptive behaviour. Such estrangement is the common human condition. Subception is a lack of conscious awareness of experience. The person is less than fully conscious and therefore not fully open to external stimuli. This leads to a flood of internal stimuli, not equillibrium.1 David spoke of Concept over experience which is when a pre-planned idea of something gets in the way of reality and you react to your own pre-plan rather than to the situation. 'The Actualising Tendency' is where the organism aims to fulfil it's potential and move to autonomy where the person is able to experience themselves in a way which is consistent with the way they see themselves. In Carl Rogers's book On Becoming a Person he writes:
Experience is, for me, the highest authority. The touchstone of validity is my own experience. No other person's ideas, and none of my own ideas, are as authoritative as my experience. It is to experience that I must return again and again, to discover a closer approximation to truth as it is in the process of becoming in me. Neither the Bible nor the prophets, neither Freud nor research, neither the revelations of God nor man, can take precedence over my own direct experience. My experience is not authoritative because it is infallible. It is the basis of authority because it can always be checked in new primary ways. In this way its frequent error or fallibility is always open to correction.
In American and western culture, Rogers criticizes cultural conditions which exist to reward and reinforce behaviours that are perversions of the unitary actualizing tendency (Emberton-Tudor,L. et al3). For example, an advert encourages you to be a certain way, look, dress, talk or act differently to your actual experience. This kind of mismatch can lead to confusion and self-doubt, issues with self-image and a multitude of social problems. David's remedy to make the paradigm shift from living in the concept. To return from the past or future to the present involved stepping out of the 'the control train of thought' and returning to the present moment. He spoke of a self-analytical meditation, which he called 'hanging out with the I thought'. What am I doing? I am sitting on my backside, and my backside is sore; this is your direct experience. This is me, sitting on my butt, my butt is hurting, who's butt is hurting, mine. Self enquiry sucks. Who is having doubt. I am having doubt. You can buy Carl Rogers - 'On Becoming a Person' here On Becoming a Person
  1. Pescitelli, D., 1996, An Analysis of Carl Rogers' Theory of Personality. Available at < http://pandc.ca/?cat=carl_rogers&page=rogerian_theory>. Accessed 2009.
  2. Rogers, C. On Becoming a Person Constable; New Ed edition (1 Mar 2004)
  3. Emberton-Tudor, L. et al - The Person-centred Approach: A Contemporary Introduction. 2004, Palgrave Macmillan .
Featured image from:http://www.psychologytoday.com/files/u217/CarlRogers.jpg

item.title: Speculative research
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Speculative research is described as research that is reserved for ideas that are questionably reasonable to be researched on. The ideas may be regarded as rather speculative or may be out-of-the-box by the conventional research community.[1]
  You can do this before starting research. It is a way to find a point of fixity before delving into the research and opening the can of worms. Consider the brief, then do a mind map, list, or brainstorm before having done any research in order to map what you already know around the subject area. We are trying to create two points between whichnew emergence can happen. Featured image from:http://www.plastiquarium.com/witness/gallery_images/witness_wild_speculation.jpg 1. Ask.com Website [Online]. [Accessed 27 Feb 2014]. Available from: http://uk.ask.com/question/what-is-speculative-research Links: http://www.ahrc.ac.uk/Funding-Opportunities/Pages/Research-Grants---Speculative-Research.aspx

item.title: Maps
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A map is a visual representation of an areaa symbolic depiction highlighting relationships between elements of that space such as objects, regions, and themes. There are different ways to use maps. Although most commonly used to depict geography, maps may represent any space, real or imagined, without regard to context or scale; e.g. Brain mapping, DNA mapping. Maps usually have:
  • An orientation- e.g. so you can tell where you are in relation to other things
  • A Scale - so you can tell how far away you are from other things
  • A legend/ key - so you can tell what things mean on the map - e.g. symbols, lines, main road, side road, footpath etc
Maps have limitations. For example, the width of a road is usually exaggerated to increase visual readability.Another example of distorted scale is the famous London Underground map. The basic geographical structure is respected but the tube lines (and the River Thames) are smoothed to clarify the relationships between stations.

Concept maps

  • Can be created using the Cmap software, Freemind, Xmind
  • Can be drawn with text, symbols or pictures
Use concept maps to get an idea of the ontological network of the thing or place which is being researched.

Geographical maps

  • Digital maps - Google maps, Open Street map
  • Archive maps - old maps, google images, libraries, Royal Geographical society
Use geographical maps to get an idea of the spatiality of the thing or place which is being researched. Consider the perspective which different types of maps give to a subject matter, thing, object etc. For example, Paul Virilio talks of the significance of the plane in the way that people see the world. The 'from above' location gives a new perspective on the ground below. What are the positive and negative qualities of this? How do recent technologies like digital maps fit into this thinking and what are their significance? Buckminster Fuller's Dymaxion maps are based on a projection of the Earth's sphere onto an icosahedron. The resulting triangular pieces may be arranged in any order or orientation. Featured image from: http://www.cyber-heritage.co.uk/maps/map3.jpg

item.title: Consciousness Tools
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A set of seeing, acting and being tools, which allow the user to be able to become more conscious of their surroundings, make their lives more adventurous, get a better sense of place and time, improve their memory.

item.title: Self-composed music
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Compose some music by yourself or in a group. You can use free software, available instruments,create your own instrumentsor any kind of objects which emit sound . Have a jamming session or develop a formulated composition. Record it and reflect on it. When it comes to an ideation session, listen to the music as a way to reproduce the creative energy that went into the music composition. The kind of music composition it was; e.g. experimental and chaotic or structured and logically organised (it could be anything) may influence what energy will go into the ideation session. Music is a narrative, a journey because it happens through time. Listening to music whilst moving brings in a spatial aspect. The addition of the sound illustrates, elaborates, decorates, resonates, forms a dialectic with, plays off and writes into the surroundings. Listening to a 'airy' electronic pad sound and looking at tree branches swaying in the breeze seems to fit together. The viewed object and the listened audio object have movement as though the mind wants to attach the movement narrative of the music to movement in the physical world. The audio has sound waves which move through space. The object (the shrub foliage) sways through space although it's movement appears disordered at the whim of localised turbulence in the urban environment. The combination of the visible and the audio creates a sense of calm and synergisedenergy. The movement and repetition in the sound creates a rhythm which can affect the mood. Changes in the musical structure can raise awareness of physical surroundings, equally, the mood created by the music is artificial and does not necessarily reflect the reality of a situation. Music is quite frivilous, always subjective and emergent from the structure of the time. Zizek mentioned that it is not clear to him where music inhabits the space of the id or the more rational ego. I think it can be either or both. Derrida wrote of people coming into a world already full of meaning that structures their reality. Part of this meaning takes the form of music. Music is a very powerful and affective medium. I recommend these books to extend your knowledge further Music Therapy (Creative Therapies in Practice series) Art as Therapy: An Introduction to the Use of Art as a Therapeutic Technique (Social Science Paperbacks) Music Therapy Research and Practice in Medicine: From Out of the Silence

item.title: Collage
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_932" align="alignright" width="300" caption="A collage / mind map"][/caption] A collage (From the French: coller, to glue) is a work of formal art, primarily in the visual arts, made from an assemblage of different forms, thus creating a new whole. (Wikipedia) By yourself or in a group collect images / photos from a variety of medias. Organise a surface such as a piece of paper or a wall. Get some adhesive which suits the surface in question; e.g. pva glue, pritt stick for paper, or wall paper paste for a wall. Cut or tear up the content and arrange it. Once the new composition is ready, read into it, and if applicable/ necessary reinterpret- e.g. you could take a photo of it and manipulate it in a digital format or work into it. A collage is a good way to subvert the existing cacophony of media and rearrange it with new message; a method of culture jamming. A collage is a collection of any existing objects, arranged in a very fluid way using an intuitive process of arrangement. It could be a collective of elements thrown (literally) together. Although a collage can be themed. A collage relies a lot on chance and gesture to influence it's composition. The process of collection can be an important process in constructing the collage, particularly considering the ease of collection of images on the internet, it is important that this method is not overused.

item.title: Directionally extended mind map
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Take the regular mind mapping concept and allow the mind map to grow whichever way it feels. For example, allow a particular concept to grow and keep adding pages with masking/selotape. Turn it into a challenge and see if you can make the mind map into a loop. Usually mind maps are restricted by the piece of paper, but that doesn't stop you adding additional pieces of paper. Once a set of ideas is allowed to grow, essentially it begins to form a narrative in spatial as well as the ideas, which allows the ideas to feed off the space. Buy this book about mind maps The Mind Map Book: Unlock Your Creativity, Boost Your Memory, Change Your Life Featured image from:http://www.wallchan.com/images/thumbs/91171.jpg

item.title: Annotated photos
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Take a bunch of photos and make a point of naming and describing each one.
Featured image from:http://blog.piajanebijkerk.com/WordPress/wp-content/uploads/2008/12/pjb_prinsengracht.jpg

item.title: Discuss with 'the other'
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A minimum of two people are required in order to have a dialogue over a particular subject, brief, topic, emotion, observation.
Two or more people sit together and one listens while the other speaks and vice versa (often forgotten).
The dialogue can happen anywhere where the two (or more) people can hear each other.
It is important that both participants are conscious during the interaction so that they remember the details and are able to respond effectively.
Alcohol or other stimulants can possibly help with the interaction. Alternatively detox; don't eat meat, chocolate, etc, and only drink water or tea.
Featured image from:http://www.coronaborealmag.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/otherness-fb.jpg

item.title: Random Elements
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
During your everyday life, capture things (objects or perhaps media using a smartphone or browsing a website). Collate all of these elements where you particular had in mind this process.
Insert them at the chronologic point in the project where you noticed them. The thinking is that there is a possiblity that your subconscious is working on the project and seeing things you are not and then alerting you to them.
It could be done collaboratively in a group or alone.
It is important that the mode of collection of the object, media etc is ready at hand and available at all times (easily accessible etc) to be able to capture the thing quickly. It is important to be conscious and have a fast reaction time.

item.title: Systematic Research
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Develop a logical system for conducting a particular aspect of research. This can be done alone, but works well in a group because having a systematic approach to a group research exercise allows everyone involved to understand what is happening and contribute to a better end result and a better process. Make sure everyone knows the point of the exercise. Sit down and discuss what is required. What are the aims for the research exercise? How will you acheive them? What are the best methods to achieve them? How can being a group multiple the effects and findings of the research? Example: Six people in a group want to study human behaviour in Lincoln's Inn Field. They map out the location and decide to place each person at a designated spot and take photos of every human behaviour observed.
  • During set timescale (1 hour)
  • With a zoom lens
  • Talley survey recorded to back up photos
  • Time of day and geolocation recorded
Six people can take more photos from multiple perspectives and multiple subjectivities. The research method is likely to be more critically reflectively considered with six people (hopefully). Featured image from:http://sd.keepcalm-o-matic.co.uk/i/keep-calm-and-be-systematic.png

item.title: Spectacular Identification
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Look for all, in the Debordian sense, Spectacular elements. What things reinforce the instinct to be entranced and awed by spectacles.
  • What are the affects of the spectacle?
  • What is a spectacle - its qualities, examples etc?

item.title: Audio Recording
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Sounds can be recorded, recommended with a decent recorder; see the M-Audio Microtrack 2 or the Edirol N-09 - ebay listing. Sound is a fantastic medium because it has the ability to affect action and create energy, and different perspective in the listener. Use the recorder to record conversations, music, animal / non-human sounds, sounds from the city, industrial sounds, sounds from everyday life. Once the sounds are recorded they need to be archived in an ordered way with a good naming convention- like: Context_Subject_Name_Location_Author_Date.wav It is best, if possible to keep high quality versions of the audio recordings in an archive (buy a high capacity disk or upload onto www.mediafire.com if you have a fast connection). Fidelity is something which cannot be regained if a sound file has been compressed into for example an mp3 file.

item.title: Audio Editing & Representation
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Where did it come from? It comes from personal experience using recorded sounds as part of musical compositions. What is the hypothesis? Audio can be represented as it was recorded for reflective purposes or it can be meddled with, cut up, mashed together, unpicked and deconstructed (for example finding symbolic audio elements within other audio elements- like a thud sound which could be used as a drum). Who did it come from? -- How can you use this method? Audio software: Editing:
  • Audacity (open source)
  • Soundforge (commercial)
What is my point of view on this method? Sound is an extremely interesting area of studio as it occupies a space between the mental and the physical. In my experience, experimentation with sound is a very rewarding process. Did you try it? Please leave a comment below detailing where, when, with whom, how, why and what you did (and include a link if you documented about using this method. Flickr photo by Pindec

item.title: Forms through Sound (Cymatics)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Audio could be approached from the point of view of it's benefit as a transfer of energy and indeed form: <iframe title="YouTube video player" src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/I4jUMWFKPTY" height="390" width="480" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0"></iframe>

item.title: How do you want to live?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: As yourself the question. Discuss the question in a group. Combine this with storycubes. The featured image on this post is Martin Heidegger's hut in the Black Forest in Germany. See this book Heidegger's Hut for more information.

item.title: Identify fantasy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A fantasy is a situation imagined by an individual or group that has no basis in reality but expresses certain desires or aims on the part of its creator. Fantasies sometimes involve situations which are impossible (such as the existence of magic powers) or highly unlikely; or they may be more realistic (Wikipedia). Fantasy, in the sense, of thoughts which should not, or cannot become reality, can still be a driving force for actions in the real world. If it is not possible for the fantasy to become reality, then where is the line drawn before the attainment of the fantasy is dropped in the face of reality. Should fantasy be pursued in reality or is it better left in the form of fantasy? How does constructing a fantasy feed into the real world? How does fantasy affect people's lives? Daydreams for Freud were thus a valuable resource. 'These day-dreams are cathected with a large amount of interest; they are carefully cherished by the subject and usually concealed with a great deal of sensitivity...such phantasies may be unconscious just as well as conscious'.[13] He considered 'These phantasies include a great deal of the true constitutional essence of the subject's personality' and that the energetic man 'is one who succeeds by his efforts in turning his wishful phantasies into reality', while the artist 'can transform his phantasies into artistic creations instead of into symptoms...the doom of neurosis'.[14] (Wikipedia) Lacan- The goal of therapy thus became ' la traversee du fantasme, the crossing over, traversal, or traversing of the fundamental fantasy'.[27] For Lacan, 'The traversing of fantasy involves the subject's assumption of a new position with respect to the Other as language and the Other as desire...a utopian moment beyond neurosis'.[28] The question he was left with was 'What, then, does he who has passed through the experience...who has traversed the radical phantasy...become?'.[29](Wikipedia) Blade Runner: The Final Cut (2-Disc Special Edition) [DVD] [1982] is a good example of a 'fantasy world' and this book by Freud can give you more information about his work on Dreams The Interpretation of Dreams (Wordsworth Classics of World Literature). This book How to Read Lacan is a good introduction to the often complex work of Jacque Lacan.

item.title: The Jump
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is a technique which can be done probably in a group somehow, but mainly I would think it would be a mental or visual exercise. Initially it would be that you think of something like a spanner and then you try to jump to something completely unrelated like mustard. You continue to do this repeatedly paying attention to what your brain does:
  • in order to think of something picked out of thin air in the first place
  • and then how your brain responds to trying to switch to the other thing
It could also possibly be done by picking a random word from a dictionary and then another random word and trying to jump between the two mentally. Silence is like the vast ocean. Thoughts are like fish that pop up out of the waters surface and dive back in. The same fish may jump up over and over, or another fish may jump out next. It may even seem that lots of fish keep jumping out of the water, and they wont stop! You are not the fish. You are the infinite vastness and depth of the ocean itself. You are the infinite silence. The fish may temporarily grab our attention (the mind loves to pay attention to movement and action) but the ocean is always there, silently embracing the fish as it dives back in. Thoughts may arise, distracting you from your true nature as the ocean, but the ocean never goes anywhere. It is always present, supporting the fish. The ocean is not ONLY found in the space between two fish, but as the very source out of which all fish arise and fall into. It is said that we are connected to Source. Silence is the source. The Unmanifest. The Formless. Beingness. Consciousness. Presence. Awareness. Love. Buy Iain Banks - Transition here Transition [1]

item.title: Shapes
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Plato's Theory of Forms stated that the abstract ideas of shapes was more important for knowledge than the material world of sensation. It could be said that we need to use both faculties to provide the most productive outcome. Shapes provide structure for creating new things. They fit together in particular ways and things will particular shapes work in particular ways - e.g. a long thin hydrodynamic speed boat hull or a round ball. Shapes in the physical world (usually) behave according to the laws of physics. Shapes form spaces for other shapes to fit inside. Shapes are linked to materiality and the possibilities of space and of events in space. Shape is linked to Form although that also includes other attributes such as texture and weight. There are interesting shapes such as http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesseract. Feature image fromhttp://www.georgehart.com/virtual-polyhedra/figs/jamnitzer-great-dodec.jpg

item.title: Going to the Zoo
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Pretend all humans are animals and the city is the zoo. Identify animal qualities in humans and human qualities in animals. What is missing from human behaviour which is animal and vice versa? This technique is blurring the boundaries between the modernist idea of humans being separate from animals and instead bringing in fully the paradigm that everything is interconnected. This technique hopefully would open up some of the peculiarities of human behaviour and what constitutes people's reality, structure of society etc. Other thoughts: Behaviour of humans as an ecological population:
  • domination of group of humans by another group of humans
  • network theory, complex systems and capitalism.
Zizek says 'there is no nature' in Examined Life. 'Nature is a series of unimaginable catastrophes, we profit from them' This technique is partly inspired by The Ecological Thought and Ecology Without Nature. http://ecologywithoutnature.blogspot.com/

item.title: Physical Geotagging
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Create a map on paper, or model form. Conduct a photographic survey like the example in 'systematic research'. Print out contact sheet style pages of the photos in small square thumbnails leaving space for a little tab . If you did get the geolocation and are able to scale that to your model then stick on the photo thumbnails where you took the photos like a physical Google Earth geotagging. You can add labels to categorise and create groups. In the example below a colour coding system was used to reflect different types of human behaviour. Reflect on the photographic content and it's spatial interrelationship. The point of this is to be able to visualise a lot of photos in a place coming from multiple sources. It creates constraints because there is only so long you can be bothered to cut out the photos and stick them on the sheet. It is a group activity and the cutting / sticking process is quite meditative. The cutting and sticking process in itself reveals some interesting observations as you can see above. It is a good way to escape the screen medium but to translate a technique which is probably influenced by the internet and online mapping into the physical realm.

item.title: Symbols
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Consider the symbols that govern meaning. Look for symbols in everyday life. How is meaning coded? A symbol library of an environment can be recorded using photography or drawing in a notebook. What are the hidden symbols which exist? How can you create new symbols and codes? They don't have to look like existing ones. Self-consciously challenge the symbolic world. Salvador dali and the Surrealists. They rely on the metaphorical pole to create meaning. A rune from the earliest runic alphabet. It stood for a j-sound and was associated with year and a good year's crop. This rune could also be carved , , and otherwise. The Hopi Indians have used . It is said to be their symbol for universal brotherhood. (Symbols.com) Other thoughts:- Quantum symbols. Cover image fromhttp://www.sussex.ac.uk/weatherstation/technical/symbols/symbol.html

item.title: What do you have to do to get there from the here and now?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is something which involves envisioning a different 'state' of being, place, event, object and then working out what you have to do to get there. For example. Envision going surfing in Cornwall. Start the enquiry thus:-
  1. From the here and now I have to get up off my backside
  2. go to my room
  3. get my rucksack
  4. put some clothes inside it
  5. put my wallet and camera inside it
  6. go to the bathroom
  7. brush my teeth
  8. go to the toilet
  9. get my toothbrush
  10. get some kind of soap & towel
  11. put on some shoes
  12. put an autoresponder on my emails
  13. close down my laptop
  14. drink some water from the tap
  15. Get my keys
  16. leave the flat
  17. lock the door
  18. press the button on the lift
  19. get in the lift
  20. get out the lift
  21. go out of the building
  22. walk down to the train station
  23. get a train to victoria
  24. walk to the coach station
  25. find a bus to cornwall on the timetable
  26. go to the ticket desk
  27. buy a ticket
  28. wait for the next bus
  29. buy some food in the mean time
  30. get on the next bus
  31. sit for however many hours
  32. get off the bus at destination ?? Truro?
  33. Find a tourist information about surfing shops
  34. Go to a surf shop
  35. Buy a surfboard
  36. Realise I forgot about sleeping
  37. Get angry that I forgot my tent
  38. Find a different solution like a guest house
  39. get a bus to the coast
  40. find the guest house
  41. put my stuff in the guest house
  42. realise that I need a wetsuit
  43. go to another surf shop
  44. buy a wetsuit
  45. go to the beach
  46. see if there are waves
  47. if there are waves, put on the wetsuit
  48. if there aren't waves, go to the pub
  49. walk into the sea with surfboard
  50. lie on surfboard
  51. wait for a wave to come
  52. as the wave approaches, paddle board
  53. as the wave begins to carry you, stand up in one movement
  54. balance and surf until you fall off or the wave subsides
  55. The end.

item.title: Syntagm Shift
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Using one object as another. In semiotics, syntagmatic analysis is analysis of syntax or surface structure (syntagmatic structure) as opposed to paradigms (paradigmatic analysis). This is often achieved using commutation tests. Syntagmatic means one element selects the other element either to precede it or to follow it. For example, the definitive article "the" selects a noun and not a verb.(wikipedia) Saussure was 'concerned exclusively with three sorts of systemic relationships: that between a signifier and a signified; those between a sign and all of the other elements of its system; and those between a sign and the elements which surround it within a concrete signifying instance' (Silverman 1983, 10). He emphasized that meaning arises from the differences between signifiers; these differences are of two kinds: syntagmatic (concerning positioning) and paradigmatic (concerning substitution). Saussure called the latter associative relations (Saussure 1983, 121; Saussure 1974, 122). but Roman Jakobson's term is now used. The distinction is a key one in structuralist semiotic analysis. These two dimensions are often presented as 'axes', where the horizontal axis is the syntagmatic and the vertical axis is the paradigmatic. The plane of the syntagm is that of the combination of 'this-and-this-and-this' (as in the sentence, 'the man cried') whilst the plane of the paradigm is that of the selection of 'this-or-this-or-this' (e.g. the replacement of the last word in the same sentence with 'died' or 'sang'). Whilst syntagmatic relations are possibilities of combination, paradigmatic relations are functional contrasts - they involve differentiation. Aber University Media Archive. Available at <http://www.aber.ac.uk/media/Documents/S4B/sem03.html>. [Accessed June 2011].
  • A 4 poster bed as a paperclip
  • A sparrow as a gun
  • A nut as a partridge
  • A poodle as a saboteur
  • A knife as a spoon
  • A leg as an arm
  • A bowling ball as a pet
  • The floor as a bed
  • Eating as a way to sing better
  • Singing as a way to sleep better
  • Friendship as a tool for curing terrible diseases
  • A wad of cash as a doorstop
  • Experimentation as a method for banking
  • A calculator as a cartoon character
  • Running as a way to confront phobias
  • Fighting as a road to peace
  • Talking as a mode of music
  • Doing nothing to move an inch

item.title: Six Degrees of Separation
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Six degrees of separation (also referred to as the "Human Web") refers to the idea that everyone is on average approximately six steps away from any other person on Earth, so that a chain of, "a friend of a friend" statements can be made, on average, to connect any two people in six steps or fewer. Networks spread wide but are locally clustered and centre around the strength of 'hubs' which have a lot of connections. The network can survive if parts of it are destroyed but not if the hubs are destroyed. For an example. Take one person who you have never met and try to connect to them through 6 degrees of separation. Read further in Six Degrees: The Science of a Connected Age Prince of Networks: Bruno Latour and Metaphysics (Anamnesis)

item.title: Twelve-tone technique
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Twelve-tone technique (also dodecaphony, twelve-tone serialism, and, in British usage, twelve-note composition) is a method of musical composition devised by Arnold Schoenberg. The technique is a means of ensuring that all 12 notes of the chromatic scale are sounded as often as one another in a piece of music while preventing the emphasis of any through the use of tone rows, an ordering of the 12 pitches. All 12 notes are thus given more or less equal importance, and the music avoids being in a key. The technique was influential on composers in the mid-twentieth century. Schoenberg himself described the system as a "Method of Composing with Twelve Tones Which are Related Only with One Another". However, the common English usage is to describe the method as a form of serialism. Josef Matthias Hauer also developed a similar system using unordered hexachords, or tropes, at the same time and in the same country as Schoenberg but with no connection to Schoenberg's twelve-tone technique. Other composers have created systematic use of the chromatic scale, but Schoenberg's method is considered to be historically and aesthetically most significant. Anton Webern Wikipedia. Available at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anton_Webern>. [Accessed Jan 2012].

A novel is a book of long narrative in literary prose. (Wikipedia) A novel can be used to envision possible future scenarios. To think complexly and structuredly and to expand areas of thought and to think through in terms of realistic structures that exist in the world and with actants dwelling therein.
